name: Mahesh Bhardwaj
text: AMD processors (Ryzen and EPYC) and Intel Xeon processors are both high-performance options, but they cater to different markets and have distinct differences:  AMD:  - Focuses on mainstream and enthusiast markets - Offers more cores and threads at a lower price point - Strong performance in gaming, content creation, and cloud computing - Supports PCIe 4.0 and DDR4 memory  Intel Xeon:  - Focuses on enterprise, data center, and workstation markets - Offers high single-thread performance, reliability, and security - Supports ECC memory, PCIe 3.0, and advanced features like Hyper-Threading and Turbo Boost - Generally more expensive than AMD options  Key differences:  - Cores and threads: AMD often offers more, while Intel focuses on high single-thread performance - Power consumption: Xeon processors tend to have higher TDPs (thermal design power) - Features: Xeon supports ECC memory, while AMD supports PCIe 4.0  Choose AMD for:  - Mainstream and enthusiast applications - High core counts and thread counts - Affordable pricing  Choose Intel Xeon for:  - Enterprise and data center applications - High single-thread performance and reliability - Advanced features and security  Keep in mind that this is a general comparison, and specific use cases may favor one over the other.

name: Jordan Perry
text: AMD vs. Nvidia: Competing for Semiconductor Dominance in a Challenging Economic Landscape  The semiconductor industry is at the heart of technological innovation, with AMD and Nvidia locked in a fierce competition for market dominance. As they push the boundaries of what's possible with GPUs and other critical components, both companies are also navigating the broader economic environment that is shaping the industry's future.  Technological Innovation  - AMD has gained ground with its Ryzen CPUs and Radeon GPUs, offering performance and energy efficiency at competitive prices. The acquisition of Xilinx in 2022 expanded AMDâ€™s reach into adaptive computing.  - Nvidia remains a leader in high-end GPUs, particularly in AI and machine learning. Its focus on AI-driven data centers and autonomous vehicles gives it an edge in these rapidly expanding markets.  Economic Challenges  The industry faces headwinds from supply chain disruptions, inflation, and changing consumer demand:  - Supply Chain: Both AMD and Nvidia have been impacted by the global chip shortage, leading to higher costs and production delays.  - Consumer Demand: Inflation is softening demand for high-end gaming products, though enterprise markets, like data centers and AI, continue to grow.  Strategic Adaptations  - AMD is diversifying through acquisitions and expanding into new markets, such as telecommunications and aerospace, to reduce reliance on consumer markets.  - Nvidia is doubling down on AI and data centers, positioning itself to benefit from continued digital transformation despite consumer market slowdowns.  As AMD and Nvidia compete for leadership in the semiconductor industry, their strategies are shaped by both innovation and the economic landscape. This rivalry will be crucial to watch as it drives technological advancements and influences the future of the industry.  Making Complex Simple -,,

name: ConfigCloud
text: 1 month ago  AMD processors (Ryzen and EPYC) and Intel Xeon processors are both high-performance options, but they cater to different markets and have distinct differences:  AMD:  - Focuses on mainstream and enthusiast markets - Offers more cores and threads at a lower price point - Strong performance in gaming, content creation, and cloud computing - Supports PCIe 4.0 and DDR4 memory  Intel Xeon:  - Focuses on enterprise, data center, and workstation markets - Offers high single-thread performance, reliability, and security - Supports ECC memory, PCIe 3.0, and advanced features like Hyper-Threading and Turbo Boost - Generally more expensive than AMD options  Key differences:  - Cores and threads: AMD often offers more, while Intel focuses on high single-thread performance - Power consumption: Xeon processors tend to have higher TDPs (thermal design power) - Features: Xeon supports ECC memory, while AMD supports PCIe 4.0  Choose AMD for:  - Mainstream and enthusiast applications - High core counts and thread counts - Affordable pricing  Choose Intel Xeon for:  - Enterprise and data center applications - High single-thread performance and reliability - Advanced features and security  Keep in mind that this is a general comparison, and specific use cases may favor one over the other.

name: Xtreme IT Solutions
text: AMD stock jumps after earnings beat driven by AI chip sales  Chip giant AMD (AMD) reported its second quarter earnings after the bell on Tuesday, beating analysts' expectations on the top and bottom lines and posting better-than-anticipated guidance for the third quarter. AMD, like rival Nvidia, is riding the AI hype train, which is powering sales of its data center graphics processing units (GPUs) and central processing units (CPUs). For the quarter, AMD reported adjusted earnings per share (EPS) of $0.69 and revenue of $5.8 billion. Wall Street was anticipating adjusted EPS of $0.68 on revenue of $5.7 billion, according to consensus estimates by Bloomberg. AMD reported adjusted EPS of $0.58 on revenue of $5.4 billion during the period in 2023.  "Our AI business continued accelerating and we are well positioned to deliver strong revenue growth in the second half of the year led by demand for Instinct, EPYC and Ryzen processors," AMD CEO Lisa Su said in a statement.  "The rapid advances in generative AI are driving demand for more compute in every market, creating significant growth opportunities as we deliver leadership AI solutions across our business.â€ Shares of AMD jumped by over 9% in pre-market trading on Wednesday, while shares of rival Nvidia (NVDA) rose 5%. Shares of Intel (INTC) were up 2%.  for more,

text: AMD Acquires Finnish AI Startup Silo AI for $665M ğŸ¤  AMD is making waves in the AI space with its largest European acquisition in a decade. This strategic move aims to bolster AMD's AI capabilities and challenge Nvidia's dominance.  Key points: - All-cash deal expected to close in second half 2024 - Silo AI's 300-member team to focus on custom LLM development - Largest AI startup acquisition in Europe since Google bought DeepMind in 2014  This acquisition signals AMD's commitment to expanding its AI portfolio and could shake up the competitive landscape. It may accelerate AI innovation in Europe and potentially lead to more diverse AI solutions in the market.  However, it remains to be seen how this will impact AMD's position against Nvidia's established ecosystem and whether it can significantly alter market dynamics.

text: https://lnkd.in/ggqWNKBm  In the face of a relentless assault by Nvidia, a smarting AMD hits back with its own combat strategies.  AMD was on a survival mode for some time now, fighting Intel on one side and Nvidia on the other. While the rivals went to the bank laughing all the way, AMD was nursing it's wounds.  AMD has major deals with server OEMs and cloud service providers such as Dell Technologies, Hewlett Packard Enterprise, Supermicro and Microsoft Azure, helping the company to aim for $4 billion in data center GPU revenue for the entire year 2024.  However this is a fraction of the $19.4 billion Nvidia made from data center compute products in Q1'24 alone.  âœ…Has â€œno choiceâ€ but to â€œdramaticallyâ€ increase its investments in AI and release accelerator chips at a faster cadence, Will release a new data center GPU every year instead of every two years. âœ… Will offer significantly greater high-bandwidth memory than Nvidiaâ€™s H200 with its 288-GB Instinct MI325X. AMD believes that Nvidia very deliberately stepped on the accelerator to crowd out competition.  Crucially, the MI325X will feature an HBM3e high-bandwidth memory capacity of 288 GB, which is an area that has become critical in generative AI computing due to the increasingly gigantic models that are used to enable cutting-edge capabilities.  âœ…Embrace open software and open standards, which will prevent customers from getting locked into working with one vendor.  Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang loves locking-in his customers. He famously declared in his Computex keynote earlier this month. â€œOur basic philosophy is very simple: build the entire data center scale, disaggregate it and sell it to you in parts on a one-year rhythm, and we push everything to the technology limits,â€  While AMD traditionally championed open source drivers for Linux, its current efforts are viewed as "not serious" by the developer community as compared to Nvidia's quasi standard which quickly dominated the bourses. âœ…AMD also believes that it has scored a point over it's rival because customers are exploring alternatives due to pricing and availability reasons. However Nvidiaâ€™s current-generation GPUs like the H100 are becoming easier to obtain after several months of shortages. âœ…But customers continue to prefer Nvidia because of its pervasive software stack. Familiarity in this case apparently breeds loyalty!

name: Frank Cruz
text: I often hear some outdated comments regarding AMD. So I asked Microsoft Copilot to give me a quick "Myth vs Facts" regarding the old AMD vs Intel CPU debate, this is what it had to say:  "There are several myths surrounding the AMD vs. Intel debate. Here are a few common ones:  âŒ Myth 1: Intel is always faster than AMD âœ… Fact: This myth stems from Intelâ€™s dominance in single-threaded performance in the past. However, the AMD Ryzen CPUs have shown competitive or even superior single-threaded performance compared to Intelâ€™s offering. On top of that, AMD has historically taken the lead in multi-threaded performance  âŒ Myth 2: AMD laptops are only suitable for budget-conscious buyers. âœ… Fact: AMD offers a range of processors that cater to both budget and high-end markets. Their Ryzen Pro series, for example, is designed specifically for business use, offering features like enhanced security and manageability  âŒ Myth 3: Intel CPUs are more reliable. âœ… Fact: Both AMD and Intel produce reliable CPUs. But this myth might have some truth on it, just the other way around if we consider Intelâ€™s 13th and 14th generation CPUs have been experiencing stability issues.  âŒ Myth 4: AMD CPUs run hotter than Intel CPUs âœ… Fact: This myth is outdated. Modern AMD CPUs, especially those based on the Zen architecture, have improved thermal efficiency and often run cooler than comparable Intel models.  âŒ Myth 5: Intel CPUs are always better for business laptops. âœ… Fact: AMDâ€™s Ryzen processors have made significant strides in performance and efficiency, often surpassing Intelâ€™s offerings. AMD laptops often provide better multi-core performance and battery life, which can be beneficial for business tasks."  *Please note this content is my own.

name: Mandeep AUjla
text: hashtag #AMD Q3 Revenue Forecast Exceeds Analyst Estimates, AI Processors Drive Growth  Highlights:  AMD shares surged after exceeding Q3 revenue expectations.  Revenue forecast for the quarter is ~$6.7 billion, above analyst estimates of $6.62 billion. Strong demand for AI processors (MI300) is driving growth. AMD raised its annual sales target for MI300 products to $4.5 billion.  AI Processor Growth:  MI300 revenue exceeded $1 billion in Q2. AMD plans to release new AI processors annually. Strong demand from cloud and enterprise customers for Instinct MI300X products.  Overall Q2 Results:  Q2 revenue rose 8.9% to $5.84 billion, beating analyst expectations. Earnings per share reached 69 cents, exceeding projections of 68 cents. Data center unit sales reached $2.8 billion, more than double the prior year. PC chip sales grew 49% to $1.5 billion. Gaming sales declined 59% to $648 million due to maturing consoles.  Industry Context:  AMD is Nvidia's main competitor in the AI accelerator market. Investors are concerned about the pace of return on investment in AI infrastructure. AMD's Q3 report precedes earnings reports from other major chipmakers this week.  Note:  While AI processors are a growth area, other sectors like gaming and embedded chips face challenges.

name: Matthias Hohensee
position: Bureau Chief Silicon Valley at Wirtschaftswoche, Moderator, Speaker
text: Stories of world-famous companies almost being swallowed up by a larger competitor and thus almost never becoming famous are part of Silicon Valley folklore.   The most famous example is, which was almost sold to its competitor Excite for 750,000 dollars in 1999. Or, which wanted to take overfor almost one billion dollars. And of course there is also an anecdote about, currently one of the most highly valued companies in the world thanks to its AI chips. In 2006, chip manufacturerwanted to enter the graphics card industry and considered acquiring Nvidia. The deal fell through because Nvidia boss Jensen Huang and the then AMD CEO Hector Ruiz were unable to reach an agreement. AMD bought ATI instead.  Google, Meta and Nvidia are now among the most influential companies in the tech industry. Excite, on the other hand, no longer exists. Yahoo - now a mere shadow of its former self - is owned by the investment company Apollo Management. But AMD, which almost went bankrupt due to the high debt burden from the ATI purchase, has really blossomed under its current boss Lisa Su.  What's more, AMD, which, like Nvidia, has its headquarters in Santa Clara in Silicon Valley, has become Nvidia's most important competitor. AMD is the number 2 in the market for AI accelerators, ahead ofwith its Gaudi series and Google with Tensor, that is mainly used internally. The gap to Nvidia is, of course, huge. Nvidia's sales of AI accelerators are estimated at 105 billion dollars this year, while AMD will probably reach five billion dollars.  Now AMD boss Lisa Su is making a big purchase. The expertise to expand the market position is to come from, or more precisely from its engineers. The strategy behind these and other acquisitions - and why the ATI deal should be a warning.

text: AMD recently announced plans to begin mass production of its MI325X AI chip in Q4 2024, with availability expected in early 2025. The MI325X, aimed at competing withâ€™s Blackwell architecture, will feature a new type of memory to boost AI calculations. AMD also revealed that its next-generation MI350 series, set for release in the second half of 2025, will offer significant performance gains through a new architecture and increased memory.  Despite these developments, AMDâ€™s shares fell 5% after the announcement, possibly due to the absence of new cloud-computing customers. However, demand for AI processors continues to soar, driving AMDâ€™s AI chip forecast to $4.5 billion for 2024. AMDâ€™s data center revenue is expected to hit $12.83 billion this year, while Nvidia leads with $110.36 billion.  AMD also introduced new server CPUs and PC chips based on Zen 5 architecture, designed to optimize AI processing and support applications likeâ€™s Copilot+. Analysts continue to monitor rising earnings expectations as AMD and Nvidia trade at more than 33 times forward earnings estimates. name: Abdul Kader Prince
position: Social Media Strategy | Digital Marketing | Web3 Expert | Content Creator | Brand Strategy | Team Leadership
text: Cloud GPUs: The Future of High-Performance Computing! From NVIDIA's H100 to AMD. Here's Why ğŸ§µ  The era of constraints is over. Cloud GPUs are revolutionizing industries from gaming to research. No longer are organizations bound by the limitations of on-premises hardware.  Why Cloud GPUs are Essential:  Scalability: Instantly scale compute resources up or down to meet fluctuating demands, optimizing costs and performance.  Accessibility: Break down geographical barriers and provide global access to cutting-edge hardware.  Cost-Efficiency: Eliminate the upfront costs of purchasing and maintaining expensive GPUs.  Acceleration: Focus on core competencies while leveraging cloud-based GPUs to accelerate development and time-to-market.  The cloud offers a diverse range of GPUs to suit various workloads: NVIDIA GPUs: Renowned for their performance in , AI, and data science, with models like the RTX series for real-time and the H100 for accelerated computing.  GPUs: Offering competitive pricing and strong performance for a wide range of applications, including gaming and machine learning   Specialized GPUs: Explore options like's Tensor Processing Units (TPUs) for AI and machine learning workloads.  By strategically selecting the right cloud GPU, organizations can optimize performance, cost, and energy efficiency.  To fully harness the power of cloud GPUs, businesses must adopt a cloud-first mindset. By leveraging cloud-based platforms and integrating GPU-accelerated workloads, organizations can gain a competitive edge.

name: gAI ventures
text: AMD is challenging Nvidia's stronghold in AI computation which underscores AI infrastructure's growth. AMDs latest acquisition marks a significant shift in the AI hardware race.  Here's why it matters.  1. Data Center Expertise:, with its deep experience in designing and manufacturing data center equipment, brings crucial knowledge to AMD.  2. End-to-End AI Solutions: By integrating ZT's capabilities, AMD aims to offer comprehensive AI infrastructure solutions - encompassing chips, software, and system designs that are becoming essential as AI workloads demand tighter integration between hardware and software.  3. AI Training Clusters:CEO Lisa Su highlighted ZT's value in helping customers build next-generation AI training clusters. As models like GPT-4 push the boundaries of scale, the ability to design and optimize massive AI training infrastructure becomes a key differentiator.  4. Competing with Nvidia's Ecosystem: This acquisition mirrors Nvidia's strategy of building a complete AI ecosystem. NVIDIA's purchase of Mellanox Technologies in 2020 for $7 billion similarly aimed to enhance its data transfer capabilities for AI applications.  AMD has raised its AI chip sales forecast to $4.5 billion for this year, reflecting the explosive growth in demand for AI computation resources. The trend towards acquiring system-level expertise (as seen with AMD's purchases of,, and now ZT) indicates that chip design alone is no longer sufficient in the AI era.  The needs of major cloud providers like and are shaping the strategies of chip makers, driving them to offer more comprehensive and customizable solutions.  As AI becomes central to more industries, the competition to provide the underlying infrastructure is intensifying, with implications for cloud computing, edge AI, and enterprise AI deployments.  The AI revolution is not just about algorithms and models - it's equally about the hardware that powers these innovations.

name: William W Collins

text: AMD Stock: Buy, Sell, or Hold?  by newsfeedback@fool.com (Dani Cook) via The Motley Fool ([Global] oracle cloud)  URL:  Chip stocks have captivated Wall Street since the start of last year. An explosion of growth in the artificial intelligence (AI) market highlighted the crucial role chipmakers have to play in the industry's development. As a result, companies like Nvidia and Advanced Micro Devices (NASDAQ: AMD) rallied and made for attractive ways to invest in the budding AI industry.  Yet AMD's stock is arguably the more compelling buy between the two. The company's market cap is currently $255 billion, compared to Nvidia's, which reached over $3 trillion this year. The considerable difference suggests AMD could have far more room to run than Nvidia in the coming years.  These companies are active in the same high-growth industries. Meanwhile, AMD is investing heavily into AI to catch up to its rival and is already seeing promising results, according to this latest earnings release.  So, here's why now is an excellent time to buy AMD stock before it's too late.  AMD's rivalry with Nvidia is heating up after a recent acquisition  Nvidia's business surged last year as its AI graphics processing units (GPUs) became the go-to for many developers worldwide. The chipmaker's success shed light on how far AMD fell behind in the industry, unable to immediately begin supplying its chips to AI-minded companies. However, AMD hastily worked to catch up, unveiling a line of AI GPUs that attracted prominent cloud companies like Microsoft's Azure, Meta Platforms, and Oracle.  Meanwhile, a Reuters report from Aug. 19 revealed AMD is bolstering its competitive edge by acquiring server maker ZT Systems for $5 billion. The move will expand AMD's access to powerful AI chips and hardware, strengthening its position against Nvidia. Training AI models requires intensive workloads, combining thousands of chips to power massive server systems. ZT Systems should help AMD do this more efficiently, allowing it to release its latest AI GPUs more quickly at a scale necessary for cloud platforms like Azure.  "The main way (ZT Systems) is additive to the company is we sell more GPUs," AMD CEO Lisa Su said. AMD expects the purchase to positively affect its earnings as early as the end of 2025.  A new acquisition that will expand AMD's AI chip output strengthens the bullish argument for its stock. One of the biggest differences between AMD and Nvidia is the scale of their businesses, suggesting this is a step in the right direction.  A diversified business model that exposes investors to multiple areas of tech  Data from Grand View Research shows the AI market hit nearly $200 billion last year and is on track to reach just under $2 trillion by 2030. As a result, it's no surprise that AMD dove head-first into the industry. However, the company has a long history of growth before its recent AI expansion, providing growth catalysts through...

text: ğ•¾ğ–Šğ–“ğ–ğ–‘ğ–Š ğ–’ğ–†ğ–ˆğ–šğ–‘ğ–†ğ–— ğ–‰ğ–Šğ–Œğ–Šğ–“ğ–Šğ–—ğ–†ğ–™ğ–ğ–”ğ–“ (AMD) is a progressive eye condition that primarily affects older adults, leading to the deterioration of the macula, the central part of the retina responsible for sharp vision. The two main types are:  1. Dry AMD: The more prevalent form, characterized by gradual thinning of the macula and the formation of drusen, small yellow deposits that accumulate under the retina.  2. Wet AMD: This form is less common but more severe, involving the development of abnormal blood vessels that can leak fluid and blood, causing rapid vision loss.  Symptoms of AMD may include:  âœ³ï¸Blurred or distorted central vision âœ³ï¸Difficulty seeing in low light or at night âœ³ï¸Straight lines appearing wavy or distorted âœ³ï¸Dark spots or a blank area in the central vision  Risk factors for AMD include:  ğŸŸ¢Age (most common in those over 50) ğŸŸ¢ Family history of the disease ğŸŸ¢Smoking ğŸŸ¢Obesity ğŸŸ¢High blood pressure ğŸŸ¢Poor dietary habits ğŸŸ¢Prolonged exposure to sunlight  While there is currently no for AMD, several treatments can help manage the condition, particularly for wet AMD:  1. Anti-VEGF injections: â€¢ Ranibizumab (Lucentis): Developed by Genentech (part of Roche), this medication inhibits vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) to reduce the growth of abnormal blood vessels. â€¢ Aflibercept (Eylea): Manufactured by Regeneron Pharmaceuticals, it works similarly by blocking VEGF and preventing fluid leakage. â€¢Brolucizumab (Beovu): Another option from Novartis, it has a similar mechanism but is designed for less frequent dosing.  2. Photodynamic therapy: This treatment involves a light-sensitive drug (verteporfin) followed by laser treatment to target and destroy leaking blood vessels.  3. Nutritional : The AREDS formulation (vitamins C and E, zinc, copper, and lutein) may slow progression in individuals with intermediate to advanced dry AMD.  Regarding drug manufacturers:  ğŸŸ¨Roche is known for developing Lucentis and continues to focus on innovative therapies for retinal diseases. ğŸŸ¨Novartis manufactures Eylea and is involved in various research initiatives for eye health. ğŸŸ¨ Regeneron Pharmaceuticals has a portfolio that includes Eylea and is actively researching further treatments for AMD. ğŸŸ¨Bayer HealthCare collaborates with Regeneron in the development and distribution of Eylea, focusing on advancing eye care treatments. ğŸŸ¨Kanghong Pharma is a newer player working on treatments for retinal diseases, including those targeting AMD.  To potentially slow the progression of AMD, lifestyle changes can be beneficial:  ğŸ”´Regular eye examinations to monitor vision changes ğŸ”´A diet rich in leafy greens, fish, and antioxidants ğŸ”´ Quitting smoking to reduce risk ğŸ”´ Wearing sunglasses to protect against UV damage

name: Alok Tripathi
text: "Rumours of my death are severely exaggerated. We are alive and well"   Intel's Pat Gelsinger also said, "We see that the x86 architecture, this foundation of computing for decades, is about to go through a period of customization, expansion, scalability (with) the opportunities that AI will present, and our ecosystem is robust and growing." -  â–ªï¸x86 Ecosystem Advisory Group  Intel invented the x86 computing architecture and AMD licenses the technology from Intel to make chips using x86, competing directly against Intel. AMD use the same underlying x86 technology in their chips, but software sometimes must be tweaked to work across their offerings. Intel and AMD now intend to change that with a new "Advisory Group."  Read -  The group will seek technical input for "essential functions and features" for chips from Intel and AMD with a goal to enhance customer choice and simplify architectural guidelines for enhanced software consistency and interfaces on x86 product offerings from Intel and AMD.  â–ªï¸The Angle  To provide choices to Telcos the vendor needs to sure it's vDU software/solution is truly multiplatform.  This is an ongoing challenge for the industry struggling to build and deploy portable RAN software running across multiple accelerated computing platforms.  When a vendor says its CloudRAN can go on any hardware or cloud, there are always caveats.  For example, a vendor N's CloudRAN may have as an integral part a "Smart" PCIe card powered by it's custom SoC that runs vendor's proprietary L1 acceleration algorithms which are not portable to other computing architectures. The vendor in this case will highlight it's portability across Intel/AMD/AWS/NVIDIA etc. but that is only for the L2+ portion of it's CloudRAN.  Another vendor E's CloudRAN doesn't depend on a "Smart" PCIe card with custom SoC. It's L1 acceleration software however still depends on the Intel x86 Xeons CPUs and the vendor has tweaked it to work on AMD's chips as well. However, there is no word yet on support for any ARM-based option.  After Q3 results, the shares of E have hit a two-year high after it saw sales in North America growing 55% y-o-y, most likely due to modernization deal as there is nothing that suggests Verizon or T-Mobile have boosted spending.  â–ªï¸ Rumours of Vendor N's death are severely exaggerated too, just like Intel's  A vendor S was rumoured as a potential buyer of N's RAN business, but it turned out to be fake. S is going through it's own rough patch with layoffs and everything. It's vRAN contract with Verizon runs till 2025e.  A sincere advice to N would be to 'let bygones be bygones' and port vDU L1 on Intel Xeons. This is THE key to making a comeback in US story, especially in VZ first and later in AT&T when it scales CloudRAN in 2027.

AMDâ€™s new offering could potentially influence pricing in the market by providing an alternative to Nvidiaâ€™s products, which have traditionally maintained high profit margins due to strong demand. text: The Bloomingdaleâ€™s Carousel Project this month is From Italy With Love.   Panne, dolci, caffe, alimenti, and cucina are Italian terminology for the consumers.  The Italian merchandise will be grouped by a variety of categories. This week is cuisine amd kitchen items. You enter the department and see Italian maps and picturesque posters of cities.  There are colorful ceramics and glassware. Items such as spices, pasta, coffee and sweets are arranged in an appetizing style. You can browse the floor looking for home- kitchen decor by Giadzy, ceramic plates, cookbooks and DÄ“longhi coffee machines.  There are fun items such as a tote bag with the names and pictures of pastas, Acqua de Parma perfume, candles, and replicas of cakes and tomatoes.  The floor gets you familiarized with brand names so you leave informed about the merchandise.  If you are serious chef in the kitchen, you can purchase dolci/ sweets, spicy tomato sauces, and food which you would find on a trip to Rome or Venice. Mange.

name: USC Marshall Business of Energy Transition Initiative
text: We wrap up our panels at the inaugural Energy Business Summit with a lively discussion of artificial intelligence and energy demand. Artificial intelligence requires significant energy to function which has a meaningful impact for the energy industry. Thank you to our panelists for providing valuable insights:  Asher Genoot, CEO, Hut 8 Corp.  Anand Mohanrangan, Partner, McKinsey & Company  Joseph A. Householder, Board Director of Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) Data centers have massively increased in size, dramatically impacting the infrastructure, capital, and power needed to function these data centers. The future will require an even greater increase in capacity to function putting significant demand on the energy supply. Thank you to our panelists for sharing these perspectives in a fascinating discussion on AI and energy.

name: Runtime
text: Putting aside decades of differences (including one major antitrust lawsuit) Intel Corporation and AMD announced the formation of an x86 advisory group at the Open Compute Conference, promising to standardize the technology at the heart of their most important products. With major partners such as,,,, and(and the noticeable absence of AWS), the group will work together "to shape the future of x86 and foster developer innovation through a more unified set of instructions and architectural interfaces."  In other news, Google Cloud joined the ranks of hyperscalers pledging a renewed commitment to nuclear power this week, unveiling a new power purchasing agreement with startup.  And we round up the latest must-read enterprise news and funding rounds.

text: Iâ€™m incredibly grateful for the chance to present PHiLIP, our text to image generation product, at the AMD Advancing AI 2024 event alongside Freddy Songand. Engaging with these experts and seeing their interest in our live demo firsthand was an incredible experience! ğŸ’¥  A huge thank you to,,, and the rest of the AMD team for hosting such a well-planned event. I was also able to return their kindness by offering feedback on my personal experience with cloud computing and AMD GPUs, which was a fantastic opportunity to engage with AMDâ€™s vision.  Showcasing Project PHiLIP, which utilizes the AMD Instinct MI210 cloud GPUs to accelerate high-performance AI image generation, demonstrated the cutting-edge technology that powers our work. The AMD INSTINCT MI210 handled complex tasks effortlessly, and Iâ€™m eager to see how the upcoming MI300X series will continue to push AI innovation forward. ğŸš€  As a 3rd-year undergrad, this experience has fueled my passion for AI and mentorship. Iâ€™m eager to bring the knowledge and experience Iâ€™ve gained back to my club, AI@UCR, to inspire and support the next generation of innovators. ğŸ¤–ğŸ”

name: Brandon Koh
text: For over four decades, x86 has served as the bedrock of modern computing, establishing itself as the preferred architecture in data centers and PCs worldwide. In today's evolving landscape â€” characterized by dynamic AI workloads, custom chiplets, and advancements in 3D packaging and system architectures â€” the importance of a robust and expanding x86 ecosystem is more crucial than ever.  outcomes are:-  1) Enhancing customer choice and compatibility across hardware and software, while accelerating their ability to benefit from new, cutting-edge features. 2) Simplifying architectural guidelines to enhance software consistency and standardize interfaces across x86 product offerings from Intel and AMD. 3) Enabling greater and more efficient integration of new capabilities into operating systems, frameworks and applications.  That's how we scale the standard.

name: Chilly C.
text: What are your thoughts on the semiconductor value chain?   The semiconductor value chain is a cornerstone of technology and economy, yet it is often overlooked. As a manager specializing in brand marketing and intellectual property strategy, here are my insights on this value chain:  1. Model: Companies like NVIDIA and AMD focus on chip design while outsourcing manufacturing to firms like TSMC. This model allows for greater innovation and avoids heavy capital investments.  2.  Foundries such as TSMC and Samsung utilize advanced technologies for chip production. This capital-intensive segment is concentrated in geopolitically significant regions.  3. & Packaging Ensuring chip quality is critical, and companies like Teradyne and Amkor lead in testing and packaging, safeguarding functionality and durability.  4. Layer Key players like ASML and Applied Materials provide essential manufacturing equipment and materials, making them vital for semiconductor production.  5. Device Manufacturers (IDMs) Firms like Intel and Texas Instruments manage the entire semiconductor lifecycle, from design to production, benefiting from vertical integration despite requiring significant investment.  With the global semiconductor market projected to grow at a of 10.06%, reaching $980.80 billion by 2029, the importance of this value chain for economic and national cannot be overstated.

text: https://lnkd.in/gYP-M8zr  The unification of x86 ISA design between AMD and Intel could have significant implications for the future of computing. Here are a few key points to consider:  Simplified Development: A unified ISA can streamline software development, making it easier for developers to write code that runs efficiently across both platforms. This could lead to faster innovation and reduced fragmentation in the ecosystem.  Improved VM Migration and Portability: With a consistent ISA, virtual machine migrations between AMD and Intel systems would become smoother, enhancing data center efficiency and reducing downtime for businesses that rely on virtualized environments.  Competition with Arm: This collaboration may be a strategic response to the growing threat from Arm-based processors, particularly in cloud and high-performance computing sectors. By simplifying their architecture, AMD and Intel can better compete against hyper-scalers that are developing custom Arm chips.  Optimization Opportunities: A common ISA could lead to better optimizations at both the hardware and software levels, potentially enhancing performance for applications that rely heavily on processing power.  Future Innovations: With less focus on maintaining distinct ISAs, both companies might allocate more resources toward other innovations, such as AI, specialized processing units, or energy efficiency improvements.  Overall, this move could foster a more collaborative environment in the x86 landscape, enabling faster advancements and potentially reshaping the competitive dynamics in the computing industry.

text: Nvidia's stock fell 4.5% on Tuesday, halting its recent two-week rally and coming off a record high the day before. The decline was triggered by reports that the U.S. government is considering limiting chip exports to certain countries, specifically in the Persian Gulf, for national security reasons. This potential regulation could significantly impact Nvidia's market for AI services. Additionally, a weak earnings report from semiconductor equipment supplier ASML further pressured Nvidia and other chip stocks like AMD and Intel. The PHLX Semiconductor Index dropped 5.3%, far worse than the broader market decline. Despite Nvidiaâ€™s recent surge driven by strong demand for its AI chips, concerns over export restrictions, geopolitical risks, and a possible slowdown in AI spending by major tech companies have contributed to volatility in the stock. Nvidia has seen similar declines in the past due to trade tensions, but its shares remain up significantly over the past year. However, uncertainty around future AI spending remains a potential headwind for the company.

position: Quantum physicist, programmer, hardware tinkerer and AR/VR enthusiast.
text: Dear Lisa Su and Jack Huynh,  You need to change the state of things in the gaming GPU market. You should change your approach and create a strong contender in the top of benchmark charts like you do with CPUs. People get excited when they read about new top NVidia GPUs like 4090 or 5090. The brand 'NVidia' gets engraved in their brains and therefore they give AMD GPUs less attention.  Please create a 5090 killer just for the sake of promotion. It doesn't matter if it will sell poorly. Just show how strong you are so people will consider your mid/low-end GPUs more often. You are already good to go with software - frame generation, upscaling, raytracing etc.  If you don't want to create any new chip being closer to 5090, then at least please create dual chip cards. You could also bring back Crossfire so with two or three 7900 XTX we could have a nice alternative to 4090/5090.  The following hardware survey looks bleak. We need competition. Please make it happen!  Thank you!

name: Slashdot
text: Intel and AMD Form an x86 Ecosystem Advisory Group:   Phoronix's Michael Larabel reports: Intel and AMD have jointly announced the creation of an x86 ecosystem advisory group to bring together the two companies as well as other industry leaders -- both companies and individuals such as Linux creator Linus Torvalds. Intel and AMD are forming this x86 ecosystem advisory group to help foster collaboration and innovations around the x86 (x86_64) ISA. [...] Besides Intel amd AMD, other founding members include Broadcom, Dell, Google, HPE, HP Inc, Lenovo, Microsoft, Oracle, and Red Hat. Here are the "intended outcomes" for the group, as stated in the press release: The intended outcomes include:  - Enhancing customer choice and compatibility across hardware and software, while accelerating their ability to benefit from new, cutting-edge features.  - Simplifying architectural guidelines to enhance software consistency and standardize interfaces across x86 product offerings from Intel and AMD.  - Enabling greater and more efficient integration of new capabilities into operating systems, frameworks and applications.  Read more of this story at Slashdot.

text: Is the PC dead?  Around  2012, people were saying that the â€œDesktop PC is Deadâ€. PC towers were in decline as the smartphone, laptop and tablet markets were growing.  Around 2016, people were reporting that the PC is Dead. Around this time the Android device market was growing.  In 2021, people were asking again, is the desktop PC dead. If your work included video editing or 3D rendering, or you were a gamer,  the desktop PC still offered better value including performance CPUâ€™s from Intel and AMD, plus high powered graphics cards based on Nvidia and AMD, and gaming memory from vendors like HyperX, Corsair and more.  In 2024, ARM based PCs became a major competitor in the PC market, particularly for AI applications. This week in October,  Intel and AMD announced an x86 ecosystem advisory group including founding members Broadcom, Dell, Google, Hewlett Packard Enterprise, HP Inc., Lenovo, Meta, Microsoft, Oracle, and Red Hat to enable compatible and scalable platforms and solutions.  The PC is Dead? Long live the PC. â€¦..for the foreseeable future.

text: Hey everyone. here are some ideas for this community, in terms of investments (stocks) or at least potential market opportunities  I have added some context and data to the original article.  CPU vs GPU: Powering the Future of Computing and Beyond  As we dive deeper into computing, understanding the power behind the technology is essential.  Whatâ€™s the difference between CPUs and GPUs? Â·     CPU (Central Processing Unit): The brain of the computer, managing complex, sequential tasks. Todayâ€™s most powerful consumer CPU is the Intel Core i9-14900K, packing 24 cores and a 6.0 GHz clock speed. Appleâ€™s M2 Ultra also crowns the Mac ecosystem, with 24 CPU cores optimized for high-performance creative work.  Â·     GPU (Graphics Processing Unit): Designed for parallel processing, GPUs accelerate rendering for images, videos, and even AI workloads. Whether itâ€™s NVIDIA, AMD, or Intel, GPUs dominate fields like gaming, video editing, and scientific computing, offering 10 to 100 times the power of CPUs for parallelizable tasks.  Datacenters are the foundation of the Cloud and large-scale enterprise computing. The processors that run these infrastructures are built for performance and scalability: Â·     Intel Xeon Scalable Processors Â·     AMD EPYC Processors Â·     NVIDIA Grace and Grace Hopper Superchips Â·     Arm-based Processors  Blockchain networks, especially in cryptocurrency mining, thrive on the power of GPUs, with NVIDIA leading the charge.  The Next Frontier? Quantum! We are entering a new era where Quantum chips may revolutionize computing further.  Food for thought: The journey from CPUs to GPUs and now toward Quantum computing is accelerating. What will be the next game-changer?  Letâ€™s continue exploring the incredible potential of processor technologies. Are you ready, the fun is just beginning. Make your bets and be ready to make some sound investments.

name: AI Entrepreneurs
text: Google vs. Nvidia: The Race for AI Computing Power!!  A new analysis by Epoch AI reveals that Google likely holds the largest AI computing capacity, thanks to its custom-built Tensor Processing Units (TPUs), which offer computing power equivalent to at least 600,000 Nvidia H100 GPUs. Despite this, Nvidia dominates AI chip sales, having sold chips equal to about 3 million H100 GPUs since early 2022, primarily to major cloud providers like Microsoft, Oracle, and Tesla.  As Nvidia prepares for the launch of its Blackwell GPUs, which are reportedly already sold out, other players like AMD, Intel, and Huawei are also ramping up their AI chip efforts. Companies like Amazon, Meta, and Microsoft are developing in-house AI chips, but Google and Nvidia remain at the forefront of AI compute infrastructure, shaping the future of AI development and applications.  Image source: Epoch AI  For more such AI updates that is actually useful, subscribe to our newsletter (67K+ subscribers have already grabbed the offer)-

text: Which Laptop You Should By For   Working   1. Purpose General Use: Browsing, streaming, office tasks. Gaming: Requires dedicated GPU and high refresh rate display. Creative Work: Video editing, graphic design, music production. Business: Focus on security, portability, battery life. 2. Specifications Processor (CPU): Intel Core i5/i7 or AMD Ryzen 5/7 for general use. Intel Core i9 or AMD Ryzen 9 for high-performance tasks. RAM: 8GB for general use. 16GB or more for gaming/creative work. Storage: SSD (256GB minimum, 512GB or more recommended). HDD for larger storage needs (1TB+). Graphics (GPU): Integrated for general use. Dedicated (NVIDIA GeForce or AMD Radeon) for gaming/creative work. Display: 13-15 inches for portability. 17 inches or larger for immersive experiences. Full HD (1920x1080) minimum; 4K for creative work. 3. Operating System Windows: Versatile for gaming and business. macOS: Preferred by creatives; smooth ecosystem. Linux: Good for programming and open-source. 4. Battery Life Minimum of 8 hours for all-day use. 5. Weight and Portability Aim for 2-4 pounds for better travel ease. 6. Budget Under $500: Basic laptops (e.g., Acer Aspire 5). $500 - $1,000: Mid-range options (e.g., Dell XPS 13, Lenovo ThinkPad). $1,000 and above: High-end laptops (e.g., MacBook Pro, Razer Blade). Recommendations General Use: Acer Aspire 5, HP Pavilion x360. Gaming: Asus ROG Zephyrus G14, Dell G15. Creative Work: Apple MacBook Pro 14/16, Microsoft Surface Laptop Studio. Business: Lenovo ThinkPad X1 Carbon, Dell Latitude 7420. Final Considerations Read reviews and check benchmarks. Consider warranty and customer service. Test the laptop in person if possible.

name: Priyansh Chanchani
position: FORE PGDM Co'26 | Ex-Bank of America | Writes about Business, Finance and Economics |
text: Will Intel survive the AI age? Is Apple on a similar path?!  A note on how Intel missed the AI opportunity and didn't cope with change. Similar story brewing for Apple?  The creator of Silicon Valley, Intel recently lost a $30 Billion deal to provide chips to Sony Playstation to AMD.  This loss also puts a dent in CEO Pat Gelsingerâ€™s turnaround plan for the company. They wanted to create a foundry unit. They had officially entered into contract manufacturing in February 2024.  This deal fell through due to negotiations on profit margins. Months of negotiations, among C-level executives, and engineers all fell through.  This is not the end! The company recently planned to cut 7% of its workforce. They reported over $7 billion in operating losses in their manufacturing business.  Imagine this for a company started by the great Gordon Moore, who is known for Mooreâ€™s Law which states that â€œcomputer chips would get faster and cheaper every 18 months.â€  Nvidia, which was once a shadow of Intel has now outperformed it. So is the case with AMD. Both Nvidia and AMD have outperformed Intel by a huge margin on many fronts.  In 1998 Intel launched Xeon chips for servers, it was for servers that require more computing power. Its campaign of Intel Inside is to date one of the most successful marketing campaigns. Xeon even today has a 75% market share.  History often repeats itself in different ways. You donâ€™t run businesses on cruise mode. You often have to look for new opportunities to expand. Intel didnâ€™t.  Intel failed to see the rise of smartphones. It doesn't operate in the mobile phone chips market where Samsung, Qualcomm, and Mediatek operate. They couldnâ€™t see the profits that they saw in PCs and servers.  Other than this, they failed to see the rise of Machine Learning and AI. Nvidia is now the hero over there with over 90% market share and is also one of the most valuable companies in the world.  The other thing where they failed was on the manufacturing front. It came very late into the manufacturing of chips. Itâ€™s only now that it is expanding and building factories for manufacturing.  Basically, Intel was a design company until now. Now, similar is the story for Apple yet not so haunting since it has over $100 billion of Free Cash Flows from its iPhone and has been on cruise mode for years.  It is still riding on Steve Jobsâ€™ inventions. Yep, even the smartwatch. Apple has been slowly developing its services business but doesn't have an AI application of its own, unlike Microsoft or Google. Apple doesnâ€™t have cloud services either.  Therefore, Apple mostly relies on the free cash flow of iPhones. Smartwatches or their services business arenâ€™t that big a thing yet.  The technology sector is known for its almost seismic shift that can upend even the mightiest.  Source: ET

name: yieldWerx Semiconductor
text: Inside the Semiconductor Supply Chain: The Hidden Heroes Powering Our Digital World ğŸ’¡  The semiconductor supply chain is a dynamic ecosystem involving a diverse set of specialized players â€“ from the designers of cutting-edge chips to the manufacturers who build and assemble them into the devices we use daily.  Here's a breakdown of the key players, along with examples:  1) Fabless Companies Fabless companies focus on designing semiconductor chips but outsource the actual manufacturing to foundries like NVIDIA, and Qualcomm.  2) Foundries Foundries are responsible for manufacturing the chips that fabless companies design. They focus on the fabrication of semiconductor wafers. TSMC, Global Foundries, and SMIC.  3) Integrated Device Manufacturers (IDMs) IDMs handle both the design and manufacturing of semiconductors, providing end-to-end solutions under one roof. Intel and Samsung are the top ones.  4) Outsourced Semiconductor Assembly and Test (OSAT) Providers OSAT companies take fabricated chips and handle packaging and testing to ensure they meet quality standards before being shipped to customers.  Example 1: ASE Group is a global leader in semiconductor packaging and testing, providing services to companies like Qualcomm and AMD. Example 2: Amkor Technology specializes in packaging and testing chips, serving top-tier semiconductor companies worldwide.  5) Wafer-Level Packagers Wafer-level packaging (WLP) involves packaging individual dies while they are still on the wafer, enabling higher performance and miniaturization.  Example 1: STATS ChipPAC provides advanced wafer-level packaging technologies to enhance performance and reduce size. Example 2: Deca Technologies specializes in wafer-level fan-out packaging, offering solutions to improve performance for mobile and high-performance computing applications.  6) Electronics Manufacturing Services (EMS) EMS providers assemble the final electronic products that incorporate semiconductor chips into systems.  Example 1: Foxconn is a well-known EMS provider, assembling products like the iPhone for Apple. Example 2: Jabil offers manufacturing services across various industries, including electronics, where semiconductor chips are integrated into larger systems.  7) Original Equipment Manufacturers (OEMs) OEMs produce consumer-ready products, integrating semiconductors into devices that consumers and businesses use every day. Apple, Dell, and Huawei to name a few.

name: Martijn Hamann
position: Co-Owner & Partner @ Endeit Capital | Growth Capital Investor in Future of Work / AI
text: â€œI am AIâ€ Thatâ€™s a bolt statement but very true for NVIDIA today. We started our 3rd day of the AI Innovation US trip 2024 with a visit at their impressive HQ in Silicon Valley.  The company is led by founder and CEO Jensen Huangwho has driven NVIDIA to a remarkable $70bn revenue run rate today driven by the AI industryâ€™s insatiable demand for their fast GPUs. However, itâ€™s eventually not a race of compute speed (eg AMD vs NVIDIA), but about the machine learning performance. Forecasts expects AI will contribute $4.400 billion (!) impact across global GDP. Walking around and speaking with their VPs make me believe NVIDIA is just warming-up for an even bigger play into an â€œall-you-can-eat AIâ€ shop to â€œdemocratize" AI globally. What was also interesting to hear is their â€œNational AI programâ€ based on supporting 1. AI R&D Initiatives, 2. Develop AI-Workforce, and 3. Developing an AI eco-system. They have allocated 40% of AI compute capacity to non-developed nations to enable a more Safe, Sustainable and Sovereignty world. NVIDIAâ€™s Mission is to solve big global challenges like climate and healthcare where investments are very high.  The company remains remarkably agile via its â€œMission is the Bossâ€ principle to solve those global problems amongst 30k FTEs, who each share monthly their top-5 things where they are working on, creating transparency and collaboration.  NVIDIA showed us their latest super chip at $10k, to be launched in 2025, called the Blackwell GB200, costed $10bn (!!) on R&D. It equals 1.700 laptop compute. The system is 30x faster than the previous architecture. Tesla and Meta have ordered rumored to be 700k chips, enabling their self driving car and metaverse aspirations.  We further spoke about the fast-accelerating transformative impact of AI across various industries today. The world is changing rapidly and jobs need rethinking. What does the â€œFuture of Workâ€ mean? Most will be done by AI. 40% of time is wasted on low value, repetitive tasks and will soon be done by AI. That's positive, but has societal impact and requires re-skilling of large workforces.  Lastly, we spoke about NVIDIAs Corporate Venture arm which invested $1bn in ca 100 companies across AI ML, Robotics, Autonomous Machines and Metaverse Graphics. NVIDIA is also working a lot with startups, called NVIDIA Inception. Currently, the program supports 22.000 startups.  Finally, like in '22, '23 and now '24 we had another fascinating visit with our AI Innovation group of 20+ entrepreneurs where we saw this remarkable company is consistently innovating in technologies and services to solve the biggest problems on our planet. Thatâ€™s quite a claim and goal, but you can see -aside from all the hardware successes- that NVIDIA is on a bigger and greater mission than I could have imagined a few years back.  Thankshosting us andfor the overwhelming demo.

name: Ai Daily Updates
text: The Soaring Demand for AI Chips: A $500 Billion Industry Beckons  The insatiable appetite for artificial intelligence is propelling a remarkable surge in demand for specialized chips, catalyzing a seismic shift in the semiconductor landscape. As AI permeates every facet of our lives, from data centers to consumer electronics, the race is on to develop cutting-edge silicon that can fuel this technological revolution.  The AI chip market is projected to skyrocket to a staggering $500 billion by 2030, underscoring the immense growth potential and intense competition in this arena. Tech titans like AMD and Nvidia are at the forefront, leveraging their expertise in GPU acceleration to gain a foothold in the data center AI chip market. However, the field is rapidly evolving, with newcomers like Cerebras Systems and Groq challenging established players with innovative architectures tailored for AI workloads.  As the demand for AI capabilities escalates across industries, the battle for AI chip supremacy is intensifying. Traditional CPU manufacturers like Intel are racing to catch up, while RISC-V upstarts like SiFive and Ventana Micro Systems are disrupting the market with open-source architectures. Beyond hardware, the AI chip ecosystem is a complex tapestry of software, algorithms, and cloud integration. Companies like Google and Amazon are leveraging their expertise in these areas to gain a competitive edge, while startups like Hailo and Blaize are pioneering specialized AI chips for edge computing.  As the AI revolution gains momentum, the AI chip market is poised to witness unprecedented growth and innovation. From autonomous vehicles to healthcare diagnostics, the demand for AI capabilities will continue to soar, driving the development of increasingly powerful and efficient silicon. However, challenges such as power consumption, cooling, and software optimization will need to be addressed to fully unleash the potential of AI chips.    Read the Full Article:

text: TEM micrographs of Intel Corporation's single nanosheet transistor with various Tsi values down to 1.5nm:  Intel to present at IEDM â€”  Silicon RibbonFET at 6nm Gate Length and 45nm contacted polysilicon pitch (CPP, the spacing between transistor gates) with no degradation of electron mobility  Drain-induced barrier lowering (DIBL) versus silicon thickness (Tsi) at gate length of 18nm. shows a reduction as Tsi is scaled from 10nm to 1.5nm; however, DIBL reduction saturates at Tsi <4nm. PMOS DIBL is elevated compared to NMOS DIBL at the same Tsi.  The authors do not reference a specific Intel manufacturing process but RibbonFETs are slated to be inserted into production in the 20A process â€“ nominal 20 angstrom or 2nm process. Intel has seemingly opted not to introduce any of its processor products on 20A and instead go directly from its 3nm process to the 18A process.  The researchers will show that electron mobility doesnâ€™t degrade until a nanosheet silicon thickness of 3nm.  Source:

text: Motherboard N3 or N4: Which is Best for Your PC Build?  https://ift.tt/Ei4kNHX  When building a PC, one of the most crucial decisions youâ€™ll face is choosing the right motherboard. In the case of motherboard N3 or N4, the decision largely depends on your specific needs and the type of performance you expect from your system. The N3 motherboard tends to be more budget-friendly and suitable for casual users, while the N4 offers advanced features for gamers and power users. This article will delve into the specifications, performance, compatibility, pricing, and recommendations to help you determine which motherboard is best for your PC build.  Content  Understanding Motherboards: N3 vs. N4  What is a Motherboard?  Overview of Motherboard N3 and N4  Key Specifications of Motherboard N3 and N4  Motherboard N3 Specs  Motherboard N4 Specs  Performance Comparison: Motherboard N3 vs. N4  Benchmarking Performance  Real-World Use Cases  Compatibility Considerations: Motherboard N3 or N4  CPU Compatibility  RAM Compatibility  Graphics Card and Expansion Slots  Other Peripheral Compatibility  User Recommendations: When to Choose Motherboard N3 or N4  Best Use Cases for N3  Best Use Cases for N4  Conclusion  Understanding Motherboards: N3 vs. N4  What is a Motherboard?  A motherboard is the central printed circuit board (PCB) in a computer that connects all components, including the CPU, RAM, and storage devices. It serves as the main hub for communication between various parts of the system, making it a critical component in any PC build. Choosing the right motherboard is essential, as it impacts performance, compatibility, and upgrade options.  Overview of Motherboard N3 and N4  Both the N3 and N4 motherboards are designed to meet different user needs. The N3 model is aimed at budget-conscious consumers, while the N4 model is geared toward enthusiasts seeking cutting-edge technology. Each motherboard is developed by reputable manufacturers, ensuring quality and reliability.  Key Specifications of Motherboard N3 and N4  Motherboard N3 Specs  The motherboard N3 offers solid specifications for everyday computing needs. Hereâ€™s a detailed breakdown:  Feature  Specification  CPU Support  Intel Core i3/i5/i7  RAM Slots  2 x DDR4 (up to 32GB)  Expansion Slots  1 x PCIe x16, 2 x PCIe x1  USB Ports  4 x USB 3.0, 2 x USB 2.0  SATA Ports  4 x SATA III  Integrated Graphics Support  Yes  Price Range  $70 â€“ $100  Pros:  Affordable price  Good for basic gaming and productivity tasks  Easy to install  Cons:  Limited expansion capabilities  Not ideal for high-performance gaming  Motherboard N4 Specs  The motherboard N4 offers enhanced specifications aimed at power users and gamers:  Feature  Specification  CPU Support  Intel Core i5/i7/i9, AMD Ryzen 5/7/9  RAM Slots  4 x DDR4 (up to 128GB)  Expansion Slots  3 x PCIe x16, 2 x PCIe x1  USB Ports  6 x USB 3.2, 4 x USB 2.0  SATA Ports  6 x SATA III  Integrated Graphics Support  No  Price Range  $150 â€“...

name: Kristjan Mar Hauksson
position: Digital Evangelist | CXO | Speaker/Author | MarTech | Strategy | Advisory Board | B2B | Award Winning & Stuff | I â¤ï¸ SEO
text: ğŸ’¡ Here's a fun fact: generating an image with AI, like ChatGPT, uses about as much energy as charging your phone. ğŸ¤¯ğŸ“±  I bet you did not know your picture-perfect AI-generated masterpiece is sipping on electricity like your phone after a long day. While we scroll and create, we only sometimes think about the energy these clever machines need to get the job done!  With AI becoming our new go-to tool for everything from chat to art, the energy bill is starting to add up. Imagine every image being like your phone saying, "Hey, I need a charge!"  So, what can we do? It's time to come together and advocate for greener AI and smarter tech and maybeâ€¦ hit 'send' a little less often. ğŸ˜…ğŸŒ  On the serious side, the rapid growth of AI, particularly generative AI, is driving a massive increase in power consumption. Big Tech companies are investing tens of billions quarterly in AI accelerators. This surge transforms power usage into a mission-critical challenge as companies like Nvidia, AMD, and Intel release next-generation AI accelerators that consume significantly more electricity with each iteration. For instance, Nvidia's A100 GPU consumes up to 400W, but its successor, the H100, consumes up to 700Wâ€”a 75% increase. Intel's Gaudi 3 accelerator will consume 900W, and its upcoming Falcon Shores hybrid processor is expected to use an astounding 1,500W per chip.  The demand for GPUs is increasing as data centre energy needs are rising rapidly. In 2023, Nvidia alone shipped 3.76 million GPUs, which is estimated to consume 14.38 TWh of power annually, equivalent to the energy usage of over 1.3 million U.S. households. These numbers are expected to increase further with the introduction of Nvidia's Blackwell generation and other AI accelerators. Big Tech's capital expenditures (capex) on AI infrastructure will exceed $200 billion in 2024, primarily for GPUs to power AI training and cloud services.  One of the critical challenges ahead is managing the growing energy consumption while maintaining performance. Although newer GPUs are becoming more power-efficient and delivering more performance per watt, AI systems' sheer scale and power demands are outpacing these efficiency gains. As a result, data centres increasingly shift to liquid cooling systems to handle the heat generated by these powerful processors.

text: Yes, NVIDIA and MediaTek will be in the AI PC game in the future. Neither company has confirmed, still questions if collab or separate, nor has Microsoft confirmed, but it's happening.  I could see Nvidia targeting all day battery life gaming/workstation and MediaTek low-end/mid-range general purpose and China.  We're headed from 1 dominant industry player 5 years ago (Intel) in PC processors to OEMs now potentially having 4-5 options.  Competition is great, it increases innovation and lowers prices, but is that financially supportable? Likely not.  Don't confuse this with all the custom datacenter designs. This is merchant silicon where the entire value chain has to make profits. Datacenter custom is cutting out the merchant silicon design margin.  Companies who can leverage R&D spend with a compelling product will do fine.  Let me know what you think.

text: hashtag #ZLUDA's Comeback: A Multi-GPU Revolution for AI Workloads hashtag #ZLUDA, an open-source library that aims to enable CUDA-based applications to run on non-Nvidia GPUs, is making a resurgence with a focus on multi-GPU compatibility for AI workloads.  â¡ï¸The Revival and New Goals After a period of inactivity, ZLUDA is being revitalized with the goal of providing a more versatile and efficient solution for AI researchers and developers. The new iteration of ZLUDA will emphasize:  â¡ï¸Multi-GPU Support: The library will be designed to effectively utilize multiple GPUs from different vendors, including AMD and Intel, to accelerate AI training and inference tasks.  *â¡ï¸AI/ML Workloads: ZLUDA will prioritize support for popular AI and machine learning frameworks like PyTorch, TensorFlow, and Llama.cpp, allowing developers to seamlessly run their models on non-Nvidia hardware.  â¡ï¸Translation Layer: ZLUDA will act as a translation layer, converting CUDA code into a format that can be executed on non-Nvidia GPUs, eliminating the need for extensive code modifications.  â¡ï¸Potential Impact The revival of ZLUDA could have significant implications for the AI community: â¡ï¸ Increased Accessibility: By enabling AI workloads to run on a wider range of hardware, ZLUDA could lower the barrier of entry for researchers and developers, fostering innovation and experimentation.  â¡ï¸Cost Reduction: The ability to leverage non-Nvidia GPUs could lead to significant cost savings for organizations that rely on AI for their operations.  â¡ï¸Vendor Neutrality: ZLUDA's focus on multi-GPU compatibility could help promote a more competitive and vendor-neutral ecosystem for AI development.  â¡ï¸As ZLUDA continues to evolve, it will be interesting to see how it compares to other open-source solutions and what impact it will have on the broader AI landscape.  ğŸ”¹ğŸ”¹Would you like to know more about specific technical details or potential use cases for ZLUDA?

position: Bought my first business for $4,000 â€¢ 6 businesses bought â€¢ Helped close $250k+ in deals â€¢ Writing about buying businesses and my journey building a micro HoldCo.
text: Everyone is talking about NVIDIA, but I bet you didnâ€™t know about these acquisitions made by them...!  NVIDIA has acquired a total of 20 companies since its inception, but these are the 12 biggest:  1. 3dfx Interactive (2000) Acquired for $112 million, it strengthened NVIDIA's position in the graphics card market because of the latest patents and technology, allowing NVIDIA to enhance its GeForce series.  2. MediaQ (2003) Acquired for $70 million, it helped NVIDIA enter the mobile and embedded graphics market. It was the first time they expanded beyond PC graphics cards.  3. Uli Electronics (2006) Acquired for $52 million, it improved compatibility with AMD processors, reinforcing its position in the chipset market.  4. Hybrid Graphics (2006) This acquisition enabled the company to optimize its graphics solutions for mobile and embedded devices.  5. PortalPlayer (2006) It contributed to the development of its Tegra line of mobile processors, which was acquired for $357 million.  6. Ageia Technologies (2008) Using Ageia's PhysX technology, NVIDIA could offer advanced processing capabilities in its GPUs, hence better gaming and simulation experiences.  7. Icera (2011) The $357 million acquisition aided NVIDIA in the development of its Tegra line of mobile processors and its expansion into the mobile communications market.  8. TransGaming (2015) Acquired for $3.7 million TransGaming's graphics and portability engine technologies supported NVIDIA's efforts in cloud gaming and game streaming services.  9. PGP Corporation (2015) Acquiring PGP Corporation helped NVIDIA enhance its data encryption and security capabilities, reinforcing its enterprise solutions.  10. DeepMind Technologies (2016) This collaboration and technology acquisition helped NVIDIA in its AI and deep learning capabilities, making it a leader in AI hardware.  11. Mellanox Technologies (2019) Acquired for $6.9 billion, Mellanox enhanced NVIDIA's networking capabilities, crucial for AI and cloud computing applications.  12. Arm Holdings (Pending Completion) Amount: $40 billion  NVIDIA expects the pending acquisition of Arm Holdings to significantly enhance its capabilities in AI, mobile computing, and IoT by combining Arm's CPU technology with NVIDIA's GPU expertise.  How These Acquisitions Helped NVIDIA Grow:  1. Market Expansion: Entering new markets, such as mobile graphics 2. Technological Advancements: Gaining access to cutting-edge technologies like mobile processors 3. Enhanced Product Offerings: Expanding NVIDIA's product portfolio to include things like physics processing, media processors, etc.

name: Nicholas Naidoo
position: Graphic Designer | Creative Leader | Ui/Ux Design | Motion Design | Artificial Intelligence Technology
text: Lets Talk  hashtag #3danimation  hashtag #blender  hashtag #CYCLESvsEEVEE  NVIDIA Blender  Expanding my research, development and growth into the 3D animation and VFX space has led me to create exponentially utilizing Blender 4.2LTS. With my hardware of course being anTUF Gaming A17, AMD Ryzen 7, rocking a 16GB DDR5 and to add the cherry on top anRTX4050 GPU.  So, what's the deal with rendering between Cycles and Eevee? Well, in Blender, Cycles and Eevee are two different rendering engines, and both have their strengths, especially when using an Nvidia RTX 4050.  Cycles: Realism: Cycles is a ray-tracing engine, which means it simulates light more accurately, producing realistic reflections, shadows, and lighting effects.  Performance with RTX 4050: The Nvidia RTX 4050 uses hardware acceleration with CUDA and OptiX, which can significantly speed up Cycles renders, especially when ray tracing is involved.  Best for: Photorealistic renders, high-quality animations, product visualizations, and any scene where accuracy and details are important.  Eevee: Speed: Eevee is a real-time rendering engine, which prioritizes speed over accuracy. Itâ€™s not as physically accurate as Cycles but can produce impressive results quickly.  Performance with RTX 4050: Eevee benefits from the RTX 4050â€™s fast processing power, giving smooth real-time previews and faster final renders.  Best for: Fast animations, scenes where real-time previews are needed, stylized renders, or when the project doesnâ€™t require photorealism.  Use Cycles for high-quality, photorealistic results, taking advantage of the RTX 4050â€™s ray-tracing power. Use Eevee for faster renders, especially for stylized scenes or when time efficiency is a priority. However, one could also reduce the number of samples when rendering to certainly speed up the process, but that is left entirely up to you as the designer, using your trial and error techniques.

text: AMD continues to drive innovation in the AI space with critical advancements across hardware, software, and ecosystem partnerships. These advancements are pivotal for supporting large-scale AI deployments, ensuring high-performance computing, scalability, and energy efficiency. Here are five key advancements shaping AMD's AI strategy:  I. EPYC Processors: AMD's EPYC processors are instrumental for data centers and cloud environments, offering high core counts, multi-threading capabilities, and large memory bandwidth crucial for AI and machine learning tasks.  II. Instinct Accelerators: The Instinct MI series accelerators, including the MI200 and MI300, are purpose-built for AI and HPC workloads, leveraging parallel processing power and precision to accelerate machine learning models.  III. Infinity Fabric: AMD's Infinity Fabric innovation facilitates high-bandwidth, low-latency communication between CPUs, GPUs, and accelerators, enhancing data transfer and synchronization for AI workloads.  IV. Chiplet-Based Design: AMD's chiplet-based architecture enables greater scalability in CPUs and GPUs, packing more computational power into energy-efficient chips for large-scale AI deployments.  V. Optimized Software Stack - ROCm: AMD's ROCm software platform, optimized for AI and HPC workloads, equips developers with tools and frameworks to build, train, and deploy AI models on AMD hardware, supporting popular AI frameworks like TensorFlow and PyTorch.

name: Kumar Priyadarshi
position: Building TechoVedas | Global Foundries | NUS | IITB | IISER
text: 9 key Segments of Semiconductor Ecosystem  1. Semiconductor Design: Companies: Companies in this segment focus on designing semiconductor components. They create the blueprint for the functionality and architecture of the chips.  Examples: Intel, AMD, NVIDIA, Qualcomm, and Broadcom.  2. Semiconductor Fabrication (Fabs): Companies: Semiconductor fabrication involves the actual manufacturing of chips in specialized facilities known as fabs. These fabs are operated by companies specializing in semiconductor manufacturing.  Examples: TSMC, Samsung Foundry, GlobalFoundries.  3. Electronic Design Automation (EDA): Companies: EDA companies provide tools and software used in the design and verification of semiconductor components, helping designers create and optimize their designs.  Examples: Cadence Design Systems, Synopsys  4. Semiconductor Equipment Manufacturers: Companies: These companies produce the machinery and equipment required for semiconductor manufacturing, including lithography machines, wafer fabrication equipment, and testing tools.  Examples: ASML (lithography machines), Applied Materials, Lam Research, KLA Corporation.  5. Semiconductor Test and Packaging: Companies: After the chips are manufactured, they undergo testing and packaging processes. Companies in this segment focus on testing and packaging solutions.  Examples: Advantest, Teradyne, Amkor Technology, ASE Group.  6. Semiconductor IP (Intellectual Property): Companies: IP companies provide pre-designed and tested functional blocks (IP cores) that can be integrated into custom semiconductor designs, saving time and resources.  Examples: ARM, Rambus, Imagination Technologies.  7. Distributors and Manufacturers' Representatives: Companies: These entities play a role in the distribution and sales of semiconductor components. They may act as intermediaries between manufacturers and end-users.  Examples: Avnet, Arrow Electronics, Future Electronics.  8. Original Equipment Manufacturers (OEMs): Companies: OEMs integrate semiconductor components into their final products, such as smartphones, computers, cars, and consumer electronics.  Examples: Apple, Dell, Samsung, General Motors.  9. End Users: Entities: These are the consumers and businesses that utilize electronic devices powered by semiconductor components.  Examples: Individuals using smartphones, businesses employing servers and networking equipment, automotive manufacturers incorporating chips into vehicles.  For all semiconductor and AI related content, follow  --------- P.S: If you like writings like these, we have compiled 100s of such questions in our book- The semiconductor Saga- a book that teaches you everything about semiconductors in simple words. name: Jeffrey Cooper
position: Technology Author, Blogger, & Consultant | ex-Sourcing Lead at ASML | ex-Director Supply Chain at ABB | ex-Finance Mgr. at GE
text: The AI Semiconductor Revolution: A $300-500 Billion Opportunity (2 min read)  Explosive Market Growth  The AI chip market is set for extraordinary expansion, with projections varying widely. Conservative estimates fromforecast growth from $30 billion in 2024 to $341 billion by 2033, while The Brainy Insights projects a surge from $20.28 billion in 2023 to $513.97 billion by 2033, a CAGR of 38.16%. Some analysts even predict $400 billion by 2027. However, challenges like chip shortages and geopolitical tensions will impact these projections. Despite market uncertainties, this unprecedented growth highlights how AI-specific chips drive a transformative revolution across the semiconductor industry.  The Supply Side  NVIDIA leads the AI chip race, with its data center revenue expected to hit $16 billion in Q4 2023. AMD emerges as a strong competitor, projecting $1 billion in revenue from its MI300 Series in 2024. Intel offers cost-effective alternatives with its Gaudi 2 processors, while startups like Cerebras and Graphcore push boundaries with innovative AI chips. Recent developments include NVIDIA's launch of the H200 GPU and Intel's introduction of Gaudi3, intensifying competition.  The Demand Side: Tech Giants Fuel the Fire  Major cloud providers (AWS, Google Cloud, Azure) are both consumers and developers of AI chips. AI companies like OpenAI and Anthropic drive massive demand, while Meta invests heavily in AI infrastructure, recently announcing plans for 350,000 H100 GPUs. The automotive industry, including Tesla and emerging players like Nio, increasingly demands specialized AI chips. This insatiable appetite creates a virtuous innovation cycle, though concerns about energy consumption and ethical AI use are emerging challenges.  My Take: A New Era  The interplay between supply and demand in the AI chip market reshapes the semiconductor industry. Companies aligning chip designs with evolving AI needs â€“ from large model training to edge AI â€“ will likely lead. As AI chips become central to technological advancement, their impact extends beyond semiconductors, redefining computing. However, success will depend on navigating technical challenges, regulatory landscapes, and ethical considerations in this rapidly evolving field.  The AI semiconductor revolution isnâ€™t just a new era in computing â€“ it marks a fundamental transformation of industries, economies, and even daily life. From autonomous systems to healthcare and smart cities, AI chips are poised to redefine how technology integrates into every facet of human experience.  Credit: Jeffrey Cooper & Perplexity  For more on AI, robots, and Semicon, check out my blog:

name: Hani Fahmi
text: AI-Driven OS Concept for Maximizing GPU Utilization  An AI-OS can redefine hardware interaction by leveraging GPUs for compute-intensive tasks, while the CPU handles system management. This system is ideal for AI research, machine learning, and data analytics. Key components include:  1. Architecture: The CPU acts as an orchestrator, while GPUs handle parallel computing using frameworks like CUDA and OpenCL. Support for multi-GPU setups and AI accelerators is crucial for scalability.  2. AI Integration: AI-based resource allocation, real-time performance optimization, and pre-trained models for specific tasks (e.g., image processing) accelerate computation.  3. Key Features : - GPU-accelerated system libraries (e.g., cuDNN for deep learning). - AI-powered process scheduling and dynamic tuning. - Unified memory for efficient CPU-GPU data transfer.  4. Use Cases: Real-time AI applications, AI workload management, and parallel processing for data analytics.  5. Collaborations: Companies like NVIDIA (CUDA), AMD (ROCm), and Intel (oneAPI) could contribute with AI-accelerated frameworks and hardware support.  Example AI-OS : â€œGPUIXâ€ could implement a GPU-focused task scheduler, unified memory management, and custom DMA for low-latency transfers, revolutionizing AI computing in research and enterprise applications.

name: Erudite Asia
text: AI chip startup Cerebras files for IPO! The signature "super large chip" is manufactured by TSMC. How can it challenge Huida?  Cerebras Systems, an AI chip startup, filed for an IPO on September 30, aiming to raise up to $1 billion with a projected post-IPO valuation of $8 billion. The company, known for its WSE-3 processor utilizing TSMC's 5nm technology, seeks to break NVIDIA's 90% market dominance. The WSE-3 features 4 trillion transistors and 900,000 AI cores.  Cerebras differentiates itself by employing complete wafers for chip production, resulting in chips significantly larger than competitors', with the WSE-3 being 57 times larger than Huida's H100. The company also launched the Cerebras Inference platform, which claims to be 20 times faster and one-fifth the price of Huida's current chips.  In the first half of 2024, Cerebras reported $136 million in revenue and a net loss of $66.6 million, a decrease from the prior year, as sales increased from $8.7 million. A notable 83% of revenue comes from UAE-based Group 42, which has agreed to purchase $1.43 billion in products by March 2025. However, Cerebras faces tough competition from NVIDIA, AMD, and Intel, and recognizes risks related to supply chain disruptions, especially with TSMC.  The IPO is led by Citigroup and Barclays, without major tech stock underwriters, while the company enjoys strong support from venture capital firms and notable investors such as OpenAI CEO Sam Altman.
