name: Tech-365 Manchester
text: AMD Releases Major Update to Address Ryzen 9000 Performance Issues Ahead of Intel Arrow Lake Launch  AMD has released a crucial update to improve performance in its Ryzen 9000 series processors, which faced a difficult launch. The update, through AGESA ComboAM5 PImicrocode, aims to resolve issues affecting gamers, creators, and tech enthusiasts. However, with Intelâ€™s Arrow Lake processors launching soon, AMD may have lost its early competitive advantage. The update addresses two major issues impacting the Ryzen 9000 line-up: overclocking flexibility and inter-core latency. These improvements aim to boost performance while ensuring reliability.  Users can now safely overclock Ryzen 9600X and 9700X chips, pushing power up to 140W without voiding warranties. This gives users greater control, offering more performance without compromising chip lifespan. High-end models like the Ryzen 9900X and 9950X, which use two Complex Compute Dies (CCDs), had performance issues due to inter-core latency. The update reduces the number of transactions needed for core communication, improving multi-core performance in demanding tasks.  The Ryzen 9000 series promised big performance gains but underwhelmed at launch. While these fixes offer better performance and efficiency, especially in multi-core tasks, the upcoming launch of Intelâ€™s Arrow Lake processors adds pressure for AMD to remain competitive. Too Late for AMD to Gain an Edge? AMD originally had a lead with its Ryzen 9000 series, but Intel's Arrow Lake processors could shift the market. With Intel's next-gen CPUs rumoured to offer major improvements, AMD may have missed the chance to solidify its advantage.  AMDâ€™s update for the Ryzen 9000 series addresses key performance issues, making the chips more appealing to users. However, with Intelâ€™s Arrow Lake on the horizon, AMD faces a challenge to hold its market share as competition heats up.

name: Andy Cheng
position: Operations Project Manager @ Lam Research | Ex-Foxconn | PMP
text: Retrospect Semiconductor Industry Saga  In the ever-evolving landscape of the semiconductor industry, few stories are as compelling as that of Intel. Once the undisputed king of chips, Intel's journey from predator to potential prey offers valuable insights into the dynamics of technological innovation and market leadership.  Intel's Golden Era  Founded in 1968 by Robert Noyce and Gordon Moore, Intel quickly established itself as a pioneer in the integrated circuit industry. The company's breakthrough came in 1971 with the introduction of the Intel 4004, the world's first commercial microprocessor. This innovation set the stage for Intel's dominance in the PC era.  The 1980s and 1990s saw Intel's fortunes soar alongside the booming personal computer industry. The company's processors, paired with Microsoft's Windows operating system, became the standard "Wintel" platform that powered the majority of PCs worldwide. This symbiotic relationship propelled Intel to the top of the semiconductor industry in 1993, a position it would hold for an impressive 24 years.  Shifting Sands in the Semiconductor Landscape  The semiconductor industry has undergone several major shifts over the past few decades:  1. 1986-1992: Japanese companies like NEC and Toshiba dominated, largely due to their leadership in DRAM technology.  2. 1993-2016: Intel reigned supreme, riding the wave of PC industry growth.  3. 2002-2016: Samsung emerged as a strong contender, capitalizing on the expanding memory market.  4. 2017-present: A period of flux, with Samsung, Intel, and most recently, NVIDIA, vying for the top spot.  Intel's Challenges and Missteps  Intel's decline from its dominant position can be attributed to several factors:  1. Missed opportunities in mobile: As smartphones took center stage, Intel failed to capitalize on this massive market shift.  2. Stagnation in core markets: Increased competition in PC and server CPU markets from rivals like AMD eroded Intel's market share.  3. Manufacturing setbacks: Delays in advancing to more efficient chip manufacturing processes allowed competitors to catch up and even surpass Intel's capabilities.  4. Conservative leadership: The tenure of CEO Bob Swan (2019-2021) was marked by cautious financial management rather than bold technological investments.  5. Late entry into emerging markets: Intel has struggled to gain a foothold in growth areas like AI accelerators, where NVIDIA has established a commanding lead.  6. These initiatives have yet to bear fruit. Intel's market value has declined significantly, dropping to $102 billion as of September 2024, ranking it 15th among semiconductor companies globally.  The semiconductor industry's rapid pace of change means that today's leaders can quickly become tomorrow's laggards. Intel's journey serves as a stark reminder of this reality and the constant need for innovation foresight in the tech world.

name: subhojit banerjee
position: Principal DataEngineer, Streaming, LLMOPS, MLOPS, AWS Certified Architect, Azure data engineer
text: The end of NVIDIA 75% gross profit margin?  Do you know NVIDIA's moat? ... its not hardware its CUDA. Do you know you can today achieve 76- 78% of CUDA performance using triton on A100 and H100 but very soon on non NVIDIA hardware. Does this mean the other hardware GPU providers in the next year are going to eat away NVDIA's moat? Let me know your thoughts in comments.  Meanwhile here are some ideas to chew on from the Pytorch blog post: 1. The article discusses achieving FP16 inference with popular LLM models (Llama3-8B and IBM's Granite-8B Code) using 100% OpenAI's Triton Language computation.  2. Triton-based models achieved 0.76-0.78x performance relative to CUDA kernel workflows on Nvidia H100 GPUs, and 0.62-0.82x on Nvidia A100 GPUs.  3. Triton provides a path for enabling LLMs to run on different types of GPUs (NVIDIA, AMD, and potentially Intel) and offers a higher layer of abstraction in Python for GPU programming.  4. The article breaks down the core operations in a Transformer block, including RMSNorm, matrix multiplications, RoPE, attention, and activation functions.  5. To achieve 100% Triton inference, the authors replaced smaller ops with compiler-generated Triton kernels and more complex computations with handwritten Triton kernels.  6. A custom FP16 Triton GEMM kernel using SplitK work decomposition was developed for matrix multiplications in linear layers.  7. The authors evaluated various Triton flash attention kernels and chose the AMD flash attention kernel for its compatibility with torch.compile and ability to produce legible output.  8. End-to-end benchmarks showed that Triton models can achieve up to 78% of the performance of CUDA models on H100 and up to 82% on A100 GPUs.  9. Microbenchmarks revealed that Triton matmul kernels are 1.2-1.4x slower than CUDA, and AMD's Triton Flash Attention kernel is 1.6x slower than CUDA SDPA.  10. Future work includes exploring further optimizations for matmuls and flash attention, as well as investigating FP8 LLM inference using Triton kernels.  (link to the article in comment)

name: TechFinitive.com
text: Whilst at IFA 2024, Tim Danton interviewed Massimiliano Rossi, Acer's EMEA Vice President. He had many interesting things to say, but perhaps the most provocative was his prediction that Intel, AMD and Qualcomm would have the same market share "in the long run". Although he was specifically referring to business laptops, not consumer laptops.  Thankfully, he isn't like many VPs we speak to; they tend to be guarded, worried about saying something that might come back to haunt them. Massimiliano is far happier to cover ground and share his personal views, rather than sticking to the corporate line.  Read the interview to learn how Acer is using AI itself, how processors in laptops are changing and the thinking behind Copilot+ PCs being available on Acer laptops.

name: WealthWise
text: AMD to release BIOS update to address Ryzen 9000-series latency issues (AMD)  AMD is releasing BIOS updates to improve performance of its Ryzen 9000-series processors on Zen 5 desktops after negative feedback from the gaming community, according to The Verge.  Users reported "higher-than-expected core-to-core latency across the Ryzen 9000-series of desktop processors," and now AMD has addressed the issue with "a new BIOS optimization."  The updates will be rolled out alongside Microsoft Windows 11 updates and are designed to optimize both Zen 4 and Zen 5 chips.   $AMD

text: hashtag #AIChipTitans This hashtag represents the powerhouse companies like NVIDIA, Intel, and AMD that are at the forefront of AI chip design, building the critical components that drive AI computations and revolutionizing industries.  Highlighting companies like TSMC, Samsung, and GlobalFoundries, this hashtag reflects the cutting-edge foundries responsible for manufacturing the most advanced chips that power AI, pushing the boundaries of what's possible in semiconductor technology.  Focused on fabless chip designers such as Qualcomm, Broadcom, and Apple, this hashtag celebrates the innovation of companies that envision and design the future of AI chips while relying on global foundries to bring them to life.  This hashtag emphasizes the essential role of companies like ASML, Applied Materials, and Lam Research, which provide the equipment and tools necessary to manufacture and assemble chips, supporting the entire semiconductor ecosystem.  Shining a light on companies like Shin-Etsu and Zeiss, this hashtag honors the vital suppliers of raw materials and components required to create semiconductors, ensuring that the AI chip supply chain remains strong and sustainable.  Representing companies like Intel, Texas Instruments, and Samsung that both design and manufacture their own chips, this hashtag underscores the integrated approach in semiconductor development that fuels the rapid advancements in AI, enabling seamless production from concept to product.

text: Semiconductor Value Chain with the Fabless Model, Supplier Layer, and the Integrated Model: A. The Fabless Model A1. Fabless Chip Designers: These companies focus exclusively on designing semiconductor chips but outsource the actual fabrication to foundries. They invest heavily in R&D to innovate chip architectures and functionality. Examples  A2. Foundries: Dedicated manufacturers that produce chips designed by fabless companies. Foundries specialize in semiconductor fabrication processes, producing chips in high volume. Leading foundries include TSMC, GlobalFoundries, and Samsung Foundry.  A3. Testing & Packaging: After fabrication, the chips undergo rigorous testing to ensure functionality and reliability. Packaging services encapsulate the chips in protective casings. Examples:  B. The Supplier Layer B1. Design Software, R&D Tools, and IP: This layer provides essential design tools like Electronic Design Automation (EDA) software, intellectual property (IP) cores, and other research tools necessary for chip design and innovation. Key players include  B2. Manufacturing / Assembly Equipment & Ancillary Fab Services: These are the companies that supply the highly specialized equipment used in semiconductor manufacturing and packaging. They also provide related services that enable smooth operations within fabs. Notable companies include  B3. Raw Materials and Components: This category includes suppliers of the raw materials necessary for chip production, such as silicon wafers, chemicals, and photomasks. Companies like(silicon wafers), and(photomasks)  C. The Integrated Model C1. Integrated Device Manufacturers (IDMs): IDMs are companies that handle both the design and the fabrication of semiconductor chips under one roof. They control the entire value chain from chip design to production and testing. Prominent IDMs include

text: Happy Morning Today Post is about Timing Analysis:  => In VLSI Design we have three goals are: Performance, Power, Area => For Timing Performance mean the speed of the design, and the design have any Violation, Skew, Slack etc.. in that design. => We need to reduce Violation, skew, slack etc.. In Timing Analysis we have two type STA & DTA: => STA(Static Timing Analysis)  a way of evaluating a design's timing performance by testing for timing violations along all conceivable paths.  i) Setup Time: In This Data must be stable before the Active Clock Edge. ii) Hold Time: In This Data must be stable After the Active Clock Edge.  For Timing Analysis we have used some tools like Prime Time Tool etc.. In this tool we analysis the Total Number of design, Violation, Design Met, Untested design etc.. => It will shown Setup, Hold, Removal, Recovery, Clock Gating, min_period, out_setup, out_hold etc..  ,,,,,,,,,,

name: Slashdot
text: AI Chipmaker Cerebras Files For IPO To Take On Nvidia:   Cerebras Systems, an AI chip startup, filed (PDF) for an IPO and plans to trade under the ticker "CBRS" on Nasdaq. CNBC reports: Cerebras competes with Nvidia, whose graphics processing units are the industry's choice for training and running AI models. Cerebras says on its website that its WSE-3 chip comes with more cores and memory than Nvidia's popular H100. It's also a physically larger chip. In addition to selling chips, Cerebras offers cloud-based services that rely on its own computing clusters. [...] In addition to Nvidia, Cerebras cites AMD, Intel, Microsoft and Google as competitors, "as well as internally developed custom application-specific integrated circuits and a variety of private companies." Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company makes the Cerebras chips. Cerebrus warned investors that any possible supply chain disruptions may hurt the company.  Cerebras was founded in 2016 and is based in Sunnyvale, California. Andrew Feldman, the startup's co-founder and CEO, sold server startup SeaMicro to AMD for $355 million in 2012. The company said in 2021 that it was valued at over $4 billion in a $250 million fundingMay, G42 committed to purchasing $1.43 billion in orders from Cerebras before March 2025, according to the filing. G42 currently owns under 5% of Cerebras' Class A shares, and the firm has an option to purchase more depending on how much Cerebras product it buys.  Read more of this story at Slashdot.

name: Alok Tripathi
text: "Rumours of my death are severely exaggerated. We are alive and well"   Intel's Pat Gelsinger also said, "We see that the x86 architecture, this foundation of computing for decades, is about to go through a period of customization, expansion, scalability (with) the opportunities that AI will present, and our ecosystem is robust and growing." -  â–ªï¸x86 Ecosystem Advisory Group  Intel invented the x86 computing architecture and AMD licenses the technology from Intel to make chips using x86, competing directly against Intel. AMD use the same underlying x86 technology in their chips, but software sometimes must be tweaked to work across their offerings. Intel and AMD now intend to change that with a new "Advisory Group."  Read -  The group will seek technical input for "essential functions and features" for chips from Intel and AMD with a goal to enhance customer choice and simplify architectural guidelines for enhanced software consistency and interfaces on x86 product offerings from Intel and AMD.  â–ªï¸The Angle  To provide choices to Telcos the vendor needs to sure it's vDU software/solution is truly multiplatform.  This is an ongoing challenge for the industry struggling to build and deploy portable RAN software running across multiple accelerated computing platforms.  When a vendor says its CloudRAN can go on any hardware or cloud, there are always caveats.  For example, a vendor N's CloudRAN may have as an integral part a "Smart" PCIe card powered by it's custom SoC that runs vendor's proprietary L1 acceleration algorithms which are not portable to other computing architectures. The vendor in this case will highlight it's portability across Intel/AMD/AWS/NVIDIA etc. but that is only for the L2+ portion of it's CloudRAN.  Another vendor E's CloudRAN doesn't depend on a "Smart" PCIe card with custom SoC. It's L1 acceleration software however still depends on the Intel x86 Xeons CPUs and the vendor has tweaked it to work on AMD's chips as well. However, there is no word yet on support for any ARM-based option.  After Q3 results, the shares of E have hit a two-year high after it saw sales in North America growing 55% y-o-y, most likely due to modernization deal as there is nothing that suggests Verizon or T-Mobile have boosted spending.  â–ªï¸ Rumours of Vendor N's death are severely exaggerated too, just like Intel's  A vendor S was rumoured as a potential buyer of N's RAN business, but it turned out to be fake. S is going through it's own rough patch with layoffs and everything. It's vRAN contract with Verizon runs till 2025e.  A sincere advice to N would be to 'let bygones be bygones' and port vDU L1 on Intel Xeons. This is THE key to making a comeback in US story, especially in VZ first and later in AT&T when it scales CloudRAN in 2027.

text: Intel+AMD=? to Nvidia  Those long divided shall be united; those long united shall be divided: such is the way of the universe. So is the collaboration of Intel and AMD. This partnership could have several implications for Nvidia and the broader AI landscape: -With Intel and AMD focusing on improving their processors and potentially integrating more advanced AI features, they may become more competitive with Nvidiaâ€™s GPUs, which have dominated AI workloads now. The collaboration between Intel and AMD could introduce new dynamics in the industry, fostering competition that could accelerate innovation and lead to more options for developers and customers alike. -A strengthened x86 ecosystem could lead to more robust platforms for AI development. If Intel and AMD enhance their CPUs to better handle AI tasks, it might provide developers with more options beyond Nvidiaâ€™s GPUs, leading to a more diverse and competitive marketplace. -If the collaboration results in significant advancements in CPU performance for AI tasks, Nvidia could see pressure on its market share, especially in sectors where CPU-GPU integration becomes crucial for performance. -The group could drive new standards for AI processing on x86 platforms, creating an environment where Intel and AMD can leverage their combined strengths against Nvidiaâ€™s dominance in the GPU sector. -As Intel and AMD improve their hardware, there may be a corresponding push for software optimizations that better utilize their architectures. name: USC Marshall Business of Energy Transition Initiative
text: We wrap up our panels at the inaugural Energy Business Summit with a lively discussion of artificial intelligence and energy demand. Artificial intelligence requires significant energy to function which has a meaningful impact for the energy industry. Thank you to our panelists for providing valuable insights:  Asher Genoot, CEO, Hut 8 Corp.  Anand Mohanrangan, Partner, McKinsey & Company  Joseph A. Householder, Board Director of Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) Data centers have massively increased in size, dramatically impacting the infrastructure, capital, and power needed to function these data centers. The future will require an even greater increase in capacity to function putting significant demand on the energy supply. Thank you to our panelists for sharing these perspectives in a fascinating discussion on AI and energy.

text: Putting aside decades of differences (including one major antitrust lawsuit) Intel Corporation and AMD announced the formation of an x86 advisory group at the Open Compute Conference, promising to standardize the technology at the heart of their most important products. With major partners such as,,,, and(and the noticeable absence of AWS), the group will work together "to shape the future of x86 and foster developer innovation through a more unified set of instructions and architectural interfaces."  In other news, Google Cloud joined the ranks of hyperscalers pledging a renewed commitment to nuclear power this week, unveiling a new power purchasing agreement with startup. name: Brandon Koh
text: For over four decades, x86 has served as the bedrock of modern computing, establishing itself as the preferred architecture in data centers and PCs worldwide. In today's evolving landscape â€” characterized by dynamic AI workloads, custom chiplets, and advancements in 3D packaging and system architectures â€” the importance of a robust and expanding x86 ecosystem is more crucial than ever.  outcomes are:-  1) Enhancing customer choice and compatibility across hardware and software, while accelerating their ability to benefit from new, cutting-edge features. 2) Simplifying architectural guidelines to enhance software consistency and standardize interfaces across x86 product offerings from Intel and AMD. 3) Enabling greater and more efficient integration of new capabilities into operating systems, frameworks and applications.  That's how we scale the standard.

name: Chilly C.
text: What are your thoughts on the semiconductor value chain?   The semiconductor value chain is a cornerstone of technology and economy, yet it is often overlooked. As a manager specializing in brand marketing and intellectual property strategy, here are my insights on this value chain:  1. Model: Companies like NVIDIA and AMD focus on chip design while outsourcing manufacturing to firms like TSMC. This model allows for greater innovation and avoids heavy capital investments.  2.  Foundries such as TSMC and Samsung utilize advanced technologies for chip production. This capital-intensive segment is concentrated in geopolitically significant regions.  3. & Packaging Ensuring chip quality is critical, and companies like Teradyne and Amkor lead in testing and packaging, safeguarding functionality and durability.  4. Layer Key players like ASML and Applied Materials provide essential manufacturing equipment and materials, making them vital for semiconductor production.  5. Device Manufacturers (IDMs) Firms like Intel and Texas Instruments manage the entire semiconductor lifecycle, from design to production, benefiting from vertical integration despite requiring significant investment.  With the global semiconductor market projected to grow at a of 10.06%, reaching $980.80 billion by 2029, the importance of this value chain for economic and national cannot be overstated.

text: https://lnkd.in/gYP-M8zr  The unification of x86 ISA design between AMD and Intel could have significant implications for the future of computing. Here are a few key points to consider:  Simplified Development: A unified ISA can streamline software development, making it easier for developers to write code that runs efficiently across both platforms. This could lead to faster innovation and reduced fragmentation in the ecosystem.  Improved VM Migration and Portability: With a consistent ISA, virtual machine migrations between AMD and Intel systems would become smoother, enhancing data center efficiency and reducing downtime for businesses that rely on virtualized environments.  Competition with Arm: This collaboration may be a strategic response to the growing threat from Arm-based processors, particularly in cloud and high-performance computing sectors. By simplifying their architecture, AMD and Intel can better compete against hyper-scalers that are developing custom Arm chips.  Optimization Opportunities: A common ISA could lead to better optimizations at both the hardware and software levels, potentially enhancing performance for applications that rely heavily on processing power.  Future Innovations: With less focus on maintaining distinct ISAs, both companies might allocate more resources toward other innovations, such as AI, specialized processing units, or energy efficiency improvements.  Overall, this move could foster a more collaborative environment in the x86 landscape, enabling faster advancements and potentially reshaping the competitive dynamics in the computing industry.

name: Erudite Asia
text: Supermicro attacks mobile phone chips, TSMC sees multiple wafer orders expected in the second half of 2026  Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) plans to enter the mobile phone chip market, utilizing TSMC's 3nm process. This strategy will help sustain TSMC's 3nm capacity utilization at a high level, with orders projected through the second half of 2026. Supermicro, however, declined to comment on rumors about its potential mobile chip launches.  There are indications that Supermicro's MI300 series processors, currently aimed at AI servers, may expand into mobile devices using TSMC's 3nm process. AMD has previously collaborated with Samsung on the Exynos 2200 processor, which featured AMD's RDNA 2 architecture. Should Supermicro's APU be integrated into Samsung smartphones, it would highlight Samsung's ongoing use of TSMC-manufactured chips.  AMD is expected to remain one of TSMC's top three customers this year, continuing to build its partnership with the company. The MI300 series will leverage TSMC's 5nm process and advanced technologies through its 3DFabric platform. Demand for TSMC's 3nm technology continues to rise, with major clients like Apple, AMD, MediaTek, and Qualcomm securing orders into 2026, despite TSMC tripling its production capacity for 3nm.  TSMC's N3E technology variant is set to begin mass production by the end of 2023, targeting AI accelerators, high-end smartphones, and data centers. The N3P variant will follow in the second half of 2024, with broader applications anticipated by 2026. Meanwhile, N3X and N3A are designed for high-speed computing and automotive use, respectively. The mobile chip market remains highly competitive, with significant rivalry from vendors such as MediaTek and Qualcomm.

name: Marius Pantea
text: ğŸš¨ Cracks Emerge in Nvidia's AI Armor: What Should Investors Do? ğŸš¨  In recent weeks, Nvidia has been a shining star in the tech sector, primarily driven by explosive growth in AI demand and GPU sales. As businesses accelerate their digital transformation, Nvidia has positioned itself as the go-to provider for AI and data processing needs. However, recent reports indicate that not everything is as flawless as it seems.  Investor's Business Daily highlights emerging challenges for Nvidia as competition intensifies and market dynamics shift. While their leading technology and robust portfolio still make Nvidia a frontrunner, potential cracks are starting to show. Increased competition from companies such as AMD and Intel, along with potential regulatory scrutiny and market saturation, could pose significant risks to Nvidia's future growth.  For investors, this brings up an essential question: What should you do next?  1. **Stay Informed:** Continuous research is crucial. Look beyond stock performance and focus on industry trends, competitor movements, and potential market disruptions.  2. **Diversify Your Portfolio:** While Nvidia has been a strong performer, itâ€™s wise to spread investments across multiple sectors. This strategy reduces risk and balances out potential losses in any single stock.  3. **Evaluate Long-Term Potential:** Short-term volatility is often a part of investing. Assess whether Nvidiaâ€™s fundamentals align with your long-term investment goals. If the company's growth story remains compelling, it may be worth holding or even buying on dips.  4. **Monitor Regulatory Developments:** As AI continues to gain traction, expect increased regulatory scrutiny. Investors should keep an eye on how these changes might impact Nvidia's business model and profitability.  5. **Engage in Discussion:** Share thoughts with fellow investors, analysts, and industry experts. Insights from different perspectives can help clarify the evolving landscape.  In conclusion, while Nvidiaâ€™s prospects are brighter than many, itâ€™s crucial to recognize the cracks that are beginning to emerge. Staying informed, diversifying your investments, and keeping an eye on long-term potential will set you up for success amidst uncertainty.  What are your thoughts on Nvidiaâ€™s current position? Letâ€™s discuss!  Source:

name: Nicholas Schaub
text: A couple days ago I posted about Ask AIthena, an AI project that seeks to link all scientific and medical literature.  I forgot a very key piece of my post: the amazing team of scientists I work with to build it!andare the two man army working on ingesting and linking over 250 million scientific and medical texts.  What's better: we are building these tools fully open source and compatible with a variety of open source and private LLMs.  One of the key features we were showing off at supercomputing was that we can run the entire application in a framework agnostic way. We can deploy it locally without a GPU, on Apple silicon, NVidia GPUs (on the NCATS HPC), and on AMD GPUs (on Frontier at ORNL).  We have the overly ambitious goal of making this as easily accessible as possible, so that it is possible to use safely and securely for proprietary and healthcare research. By enabling researchers to use locally deployed LLMs, proprietary and private health information can be used with the system without concern of sending data to 3rd party systems.  These two gentlemen are absolute wizards to take on such a large endeavor, both in the context of the sheer volume of texts we are ingesting as well as the additional challenge of designing it to run everywhere.  I feel very privileged to work with such talented people, and because of them I think we are bringing science fiction to reality.

name: Erudite Asia
text: TSMCâ€™s expert on setting up factories in the U.S.: The U.S. still relies on chips â€œmade in Taiwanâ€  American companies may continue to rely on TSMC's chips from Taiwan, despite TSMC's new factory in Arizona. The U.S. Department of Commerce has announced financial subsidies of up to $6.6 billion for TSMC's Arizona facility under the "Chip Act," intended to create jobs and lessen U.S. dependence on Taiwanese chips. The Phoenix plant is projected to begin full production in early 2025.  While TSMC's Arizona facility will boost U.S. semiconductor production, it will not produce chips as advanced as those made in Taiwan. The Phoenix fab is set to manufacture 4-nanometer chips, while TSMC currently produces 3-nanometer chips in Taiwan. Further advancements, such as the upcoming 2-nanometer process, will not be matched by U.S. outputs for some time.  The Biden administration seeks to enhance domestic chip production while still relying on Taiwan. Major companies like NVIDIA, Apple, Qualcomm, and AMD are expected to continue sourcing chips from Taiwan. As TSMC focuses on research and development in Taiwan, it retains a competitive advantage in advanced technology, highlighting Taiwanâ€™s critical role in the global semiconductor industry.

name: Nandini Maheshwari
text: Project 90: Moore Machine for even parity generator  hashtag #108rtlprojects  âœ¨ What is a Moore Machine?  A Moore machine is a subclass of FSM in which output is dependent solely on the present state. This characteristic makes it deterministic, well-suited for uses where expected functionality is of great importance.  ğŸ¯ Even Parity Generator  The idea sounds simple but is significant: the number of 1s in the succeeded binary sequence must be preserved as even; this is achieved by adding the appropriate parity bit. Hereâ€™s the Moore machine approach towards the issue:  States: Indicates if the sequence has even number or odd number of 1s.  Transitions: Event Occurrences defined by one or zero input bits.  Output: The output value is decided by the existing state making it a parity output generator.  ğŸŒŸ Applications  Generators of the parity type circuits like these are vital for the mechanisms of error detection and correction in data transfer and storage.  I am very grateful to my teammates,,,andfor their support and dedication throughout the project.  A huge thanks to,,,,,andfor their technology support in the semiconductor world ğŸŒ.

name: Riley Easton
position: PhD candidate at UTS researching the role of miRNA in viral immunity | Casual Teaching Associate
text: Iâ€™m thrilled to have attended the Australian amd New Zealand Society of Immunology Conference this yearâ€”a truly inspiring and enriching experience!  As part of the post-graduate student workshop, I had the incredible opportunity to deliver a flash talk about my first-year PhD journey at. Sharing the ups, downs, and discoveries of this year was both challenging and rewarding, and it was amazing to engage with peers who are also navigating this exciting path. I also presented a poster showcasing my PhD work so far, and it was wonderful to receive feedback and discuss ideas with other researchers.  One of the highlights of ASI was the chance to network with students, early- and mid-career researchers, industry and academic experts. Whether it was sharing stories over coffee or diving deep into research discussions, every conversation reminded me of the incredible community we have in immunology.  A big thank you to ASI for hosting such a fantastic event and to everyone who made this conference memorable. Iâ€™m looking forward to applying all the learnings and insights to my workâ€”and hopefully seeing many of you at next yearâ€™s ASI!

text: How to assess the Performance of a GPU-enabled PC?  1. FLOPS is a key metric, but not the only one. 2. GPU Architecture: CUDA Cores (NVIDIA), Stream Processors (AMD), Memory Bandwidth, and Clock Speed are crucial. 3. Memory: VRAM and Memory Bus Width impact performance. 4. Power Consumption and Cooling are essential. 5. Software and Drivers: Efficient software and drivers optimize performance.  Assessment Methods: Benchmarking Tools: 3DMark, Cinebench, PassMark PerformanceTest Real-world Performance: Gaming, Professional Applications, Machine Learning/AI

name: Deepak gupta
text: Last Monday, the first images of this new generation were leaked through Amazon through the two models that ASRock plans to launch with 2 and 3 fans respectively and where all the specs.  Yesterday it appeared in Geekbench a performance test of the Intel Arc B580 with a performance that should be taken with a grain of salt and that, at first, does not seem like a good option for the most demanding users. Intel launched the Intel Arc range two years ago at a lower than normal price compared to NVIDIA and amd and, even so, it didnâ€™t go well at all.  With the Intel Arc B580 Battlemage, the guys at Intel want to follow the same pricing strategy and according to the latest leak, it will be priced at only $250.  Price of the Intel Arc B580 Battlemage Intelâ€™s second attempt to position itself in the graphics card market dominated with an iron fist by NVIDIA and with AMD with a minimal part of the pie, seems to follow the same pricing strategy. This new generation uses Xe2-HPG architecture to improve not only performance but also efficiency and includes, of course, improved support for ray tracing. The success of the Intel Arc B580, as with any graphics card or processor, not only depends on a good pricing strategy, but also on its performance and what the drivers are capable of offering.    Intel Arc B580 Limited Edition Graphics Box31P06HB0BA735858549271$250ğŸ˜  November 27, 2024 â€¢ 13:54     Once again, the source of this information comes from the X (Twitter) user momomo_us who has published various price screenshots from various websites. But, the most curious thing of all is that, as we can see in these images, there is talk of a limited edition. With that, we donâ€™t know if it is a promotional launch version or if it is simply a commercial claim that is going nowhere. What do we know about the Intel Arc B580 The Intel Arc B580 will reach the mid-range market, it has 12 GB GDDR6 video memory and 20 Xe2 cores. This means 4 GB less memory and 4 cores than the previous generation, figures that should be compensated with the new architecture since, otherwise, it makes no sense for Intel to go down the path of efficiency instead of performance at the same time. What have you done with the new ones? Core Ultra 200 Series. Another aspect that also draws attention to this new generation of Intel graphics is that, for now, it seems that ASRock is the only manufacturer that wants to give Intel a new opportunity, at least based on the information we know so far. Regarding the release date, if we continue this pace of leaks, it is likely that tomorrow or at most Monday we will know.

name: Paul Sailer
position: Director Beratung Gesundheitswesen bei PwC Switzerland | External PhD Student HSG | Passionierter Triathlet
text: Successfully defended my PhD yesterday. Whereas at some point I might write a reflexion on what I learned, how the process was and what changes with the gained knowledge, this post is purely to express my gratitude.  I am very grateful for the great academic support and the opportunity given byandto work on a PhD while being full-time employed in consulting. Thanks a lot for your challenges, your inputs and helping me through the process.  I am thankful to my employerto provide support during 5 years and especially for my team members and clients that accepted my additional focus on the PhD. Special thanks tofor supporting the idea from the very beginning until today.  Most of all, I am grateful for my private network and family. Many of you have helped me in many ways, inspired me, supported with ideas and discussions and pushed me to get everything done on time despite following other hobbies, building our own little home and starting our family. Thanksand many more.  And last but not least thanks to everyone I could exchange with, interview and discuss the case study. All experiences in the Swiss hospital amd healthcare market have helped me to stay relevant with the research I conducted.

name: Sir Robert Terrence Welsh MBE, MA, PGCEi, BSc
text: MIHAS@Dubai   It was a proud moment to walk into the Dubai World Trade Centre and see a huge Malaysian Pavillion showcasing 215 Malaysian Companies.  The Whole world knows that The Malaysian Halal certification is the best in the world- Alhamdullilah and this is due to the strict standards and regulations that apply to obtaining the Halal Certification in Malaysia.  MIHAS, the International Halal Showcase trade show, which has historically been held in Malaysia, was held in Dubai, amd was the biggest halal trade show held outside of Malaysia thus far.  We were honored with the presence of the Malaysian Deputy Prime Minister during the Launch Ceremony, followed by the booth visit walkabout.  This was followed by a meet and greet dinner with the Deputy Prime Minister and the EXCO members of UMNO. The setting and atmosphere was amazing and the DPM also took the initiative to share his experience and experience whilst cracking a joke or two with the Malaysian Diaspora community residing in the UAE.  MIHAS closed with an acceptance ceremony and dinner the following night to celebrate the success of the trade show and Prioritise was there to ensure that the standards of all events that we are involved in are met with the highest level of standards which makes Prioritise stand above many other event companies in terms of capabilities, professionalism and quality.  A big shout to all involved and also a huge congratulations to everyone involved in the MIHAS event. See you again soon  Prioritised ByMunira Malaysia Consulate General Embassy of Malaysia Prime Minister's Office - UAE

name: Abercrombie & Kent India
text: Uncover the enchanting beauty of Adalaj Stepwell in Gujarat, where history and architecture merge in perfect harmony!   This magnificent stepwell, with its 5 stories and over 75 intricately carved steps, offers a mesmerizing glimpse into ancient craftsmanship and design.  The exquisite carvings and stunning architectural details that reflect a rich blend of Hindu, Jain, and Islamic styles. The cool, serene ambiance provides a unique and immersive historical experience.  ğŸ“ How to Get There: Fly into Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel International Airport (AMD) in Ahmedabad. Adalaj Stepwell is about a 30-minute drive from the airport.  Dive into the depths of history and marvel at the artistry of Adalaj Stepwellâ€”where every step tells a story!  For inquiries and more information, contact us at:.

text: This is a nice presentation file from AMD that covers the different types of lithography technologies for advanced packaging. P.20 Charts showing the pros and cons between different methods including: 1) Direct Imaging (Digital Lithography / Maskless Lithography) 2) Stepper (Mask Based) Other methods are also being used but not mentioned including: 3) Scanner (Mask Based) 4) Proximity Aligner (Mask Based)  When determining which lithography method being used for advanced packaging, needs to prioritize various factors including Throughput vs Resolution vs Patterning Cost.

name: Leanne Vig, MBA, CPA, CGA
position: Passionate about learning experience design and professional development.
text: Thank you to Brandi Heather for the fabulous session on play at our RDP faculty PD event yesterday. â€œIgnite Joy, Stay Bold, and Stick Together: Rediscovering The Power of Play in Faculty Lifeâ€ had us making and thinking about our play shapes and how to bring more play into our lives amd also into our classrooms. We will be digging deeper into play, connection and creativity in a followup workshop with Brandi in April.   Iâ€™m happy to announce that I am back in the Faculty PD Consultant role at RDP on an interim basis for the rest of the year! name: Andy Cheng
position: Operations Project Manager @ Lam Research | Ex-Foxconn | PMP
text: From Underdog to Powerhouse: How Lisa Su Transformed AMD in a Decade  In just ten years, Lisa Su has orchestrated one of the most remarkable turnarounds in tech history, elevating AMD from a budget processor alternative to a formidable competitor in the x86 processor market.  The Challenging Landscape of 2014  When Su took the helm as CEO in 2014, AMD was at its lowest point. The company had been struggling for years, relegated to being a cheap alternative to Intel, with a processor architecture plagued by high power consumption and poor performance. Critical talent was leaving, including key architects like Jim Keller and Raja Koduri, casting further doubt on the company's future.  The Zen Revolution  Su's strategic masterstroke was the development of the Zen architecture, a complete redesign focusing on performance, efficiency, and scalability. Launched in 2017, Zen became the foundation for AMD's remarkable comeback. Successive iterations - Zen+, Zen 2, Zen 3, and Zen 4 - consistently improved processor performance, reduced power consumption, and increased core counts.  Market Transformation  The results have been nothing short of extraordinary:  - Desktop CPU market share rose from approximately 20% in 2014 to around 29% in 2024 - Server market share climbed from virtually zero to an impressive 24% - AMD's Ryzen and EPYC product lines have challenged Intel's long-standing dominance - $222B AMD market value in 2024  Breaking into New Territories  Beyond desktop and server markets, AMD has made significant strides in mobile computing and specialized markets. The Ryzen Mobile series and EPYC server processors have demonstrated the company's technological prowess and ability to innovate.  Ongoing Challenges  Despite remarkable success, AMD still faces challenges, particularly in:  - GPU performance, where NVIDIA maintains a strong lead - Mobile device market penetration - Developing comprehensive ecosystem support comparable to Intel's Evo platform  The Visionary Leader  Lisa Su's leadership has been characterized by:  - Bold strategic pivots - Commitment to engineering excellence - Long-term technological vision - Willingness to invest in groundbreaking architectures  Looking Forward  As of Q3 2024, Su confidently positions EPYC as the preferred CPU for modern data centers, highlighting AMD's continued potential for growth and innovation.  From an underdog to a serious contender, AMD's journey under Lisa Su's leadership is a testament to the power of strategic innovation and persistent technological development.  The tech world continues to watch with great anticipation: What will AMD achieve next?

name: Emma Keedwell
position: Head of Innovation & Growth Portfolio Vodafone Business UK
text: Yesterday I said ğŸ‘‹ an emotional goodbye to vodafone Business after an amazing ğŸš€10 years driving the innovation ğŸ’¡agenda with customers and partners worldwide! I joined via the Bluefish acquisition and immediately was amongst a team of rockstars â­ï¸that created innovative usage based insurance solutions, smartsource PMO agreements and landed one of the first ğŸ’¥smartfactory4.0 in Spain. We then moved into the heart â¤ï¸ of Vodafone Global Enterprise and I was privileged to be asked to run the Global Innovation Programme! ğŸ˜ŠWorking with innovation teams across the world we were fortunate to ideate with top global Enterprise Customers and partners! RedesigningğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» digital transformation journeys, handling sophisticated cloud migration programmes and accelerating ğŸ“ˆinnovation through fintech and M-pesa expansions. We landed the first mobile private Network ğŸ†implementation amd it was at that point I discovered Innovation could execute the corporate strategy! My journey ğŸš—then took me into the world of Vodafone Group Technology where we drove incubators to establish new platform business models. ğŸ’¸This gave rise to STEP ( safer transport Europe Platform) ğŸšŒenhancing road safety , digital asset broker ( pairpoint- sim trust blockchain for IOT) and Drones ğŸšAPI strategy. We learnt to move at pace and scale utilising the three lenses of desirability, feasibility and viability! The Innovation Factory ğŸš€in partnership with Tomorrow Street & Accenture was born! We also had a lot of fun spending time in our customers shoes! Covid ğŸ¯hit the world hard but our Innovation factory moved to digital and helped our critical infrastructure customers to innovate ğŸ’¡to operate. Focusing on ux design, prototyping, testing and cocreating on site with our customers during Covid is one of my most â¤ï¸proudest career highlights! In 2023 my travels took me to VBUK and we joined the growth products together with Innovation. name: RNIB
text: How can a sighted person gain more understanding of what blind and partially sighted people see?  RNIB Eyeware is an innovative new app which immerses users in experiences of sight loss by applying filters for eight eye conditions, which can be adjusted for severity.  It enables friends and family, and health and other professionals to better understand what blind and partially sighted people experience. Itâ€™s also a way to highlight the importance of accessibility - products, services, street design, and workplace adjustments.  RNIB Eyeware is available for both iOS and Android, and can also be accessed via your mobile browser. And if you use the app with a simple VR headset viewer for your phone, youâ€™ll get an amazing immersive experience.  Funds for RNIB Eyeware were raised by players ofand awarded by the Postcode Care Trust.  Read more about RNIB Eyeware:    [Image descriptions:  Image 1: What a person with age-related macular degeneration (AMD) might see while watching television. On screen, a man wearing a blue suit is being interviewed on a news programme against a red background but the image is very distorted as are the surroundings in the living room.  Image 2: White campervan parked in the street. Only the wheel and a small part of the vehicle are visible in the centre of the visual field due to a filter which simulates what someone with retinitis pigmentosa (RP) might see.  Image 3: A busy street in central London with shops on one side and the road on the other. A filter simulating what someone with diabetic retinopathy might see has been applied making the image look unclear.  Image 4: Hazel Johnstone from Peopleâ€™s Postcode Lottery and RNIBâ€™s Jim Sanders. Jim is showing a pink and green cardboard VR headset with an RNIB logo to Hazel, and a screen behind them is dislaying a simulation from the Eyeware app.]

name: Academy of Management Discoveries
text: ğŸ’¡ Who really controls workplace technology?  We often see workplace technology as neutralâ€”a tool shaped by how employees use it. But in reality, developers are at the center of a complex balancing act, navigating competing demands from high-powered managers, low-powered workers, and external stakeholders like policymakers, activists, and progressive employers. The challenge becomes even more complex because many developers work across multiple client organizations. This raises the question: How do developers influence workplace technologies and navigate these power dynamics?  A recentDiscoveries study by Jenna E. Myers uncovers two pathways through which developers of a digital manufacturing monitoring tool managed these tensions:  ğŸš€ Developers addressed cross-occupational differences by reconciling the conflicting needs of managers and workers, encoding workers' preferences into design prototypes. ğŸš€ When managers resisted features designed for workers, developers strategically limited managerial pushback and released inclusive updates.  Key takeaways- ğŸŒŸ Developers arenâ€™t just technologistsâ€”theyâ€™re power brokers. ğŸŒŸBalancing stakeholder demands requires strategies that prioritize inclusivity without alienating decision-makers. ğŸŒŸFuture research should explore how developers can challenge traditional managerial control while fostering equity across organizations.  The challenge ahead is: How do we empower technology architects to design tools that prioritize fairness and inclusivity in the workplace?  Check out thearticle (see the link below)       (The special issue on The Future of Work was edited by,,,,,,, Ashley W., and)  AMD Editors and Associate Editors:(Co-Editor)(Co-Editor)

name: Steven Wood
position: Managing Director, Chief Operating Officer, Operations Director of over 30 years experience in the Food Manufacturing Industry
text: In  hashtag #leadership the ability to give â€¦. And take â€¦.effective feedback is one of the true differentiators between the best and the rest  On one side (giving) is a skill that requires a powerful combination of objectivity, empathy and precision. Whilst on the over (taking) requires us to be open, put the ego away, and be growth orientated. It also requires consideration of the environment and the mood of the other person in the equation  Typically we see a situation where all too often focus excessively on one form of feedback, without a balanced approach. We also see a world where leaders are reluctant to take feedback on themselves, as such having little visibility on how they are viewed by those around them  These two faults are hugely disengaging. To be excessively criticised or overly praised is of no benefit to anybody. Equally to have a leader who is not interested in receiving feedback means we simply look at them as robots with no care for the views of those around them  And yet - when we can get it right - it makes a huge difference. When a leader can balance their coaching and mentoring responsibilities and provide colleagues with intelligent, well meaning and constructive feedback we become hugely engaged and committed - we see a leader interested in our development as people and willing to put the time and effort into us  Equality when a leader is prepared to take feedback we see a fellow human being, trying to listen and get better as a person before they focus on those around them - we like to see vulnerability and accepting feedback is a genuine way makes us look and feel like human beings  It is therefore a balanced 4 way approach we are seeking to achieve in feedback which is captured in the attached infographic. The model we should aim for  - Advisory feedback - where we are given the benefit of experience amd knowledge relating to our challenges - Suggestive feedback - where we are offered options and choices to address our issues - Complimentary feedback where we are praised specifically for our role in outcomes - where we did well. - Critucal feedback where we assess situations and look for how we could have done better  All four forms of feedback have an important role to play. Both in the development of those around you - but also in the development of yourself. All should be absorbed and embraced for different reasons  When we can get the balance right and the quality of the feedback is based on specifics and examples, then it becomes a hugely powerful force for growth and development  Feedback is not something to be intimidated by, nor should it be used as a blunt instrument of control. It is to be embraced and invested in from a time and capability perepctive. It is ultimately the greatest way we can convey honesty and devotion at a one to one human level  When we accept that principle and then act upon it both in terms of what we do and supporting others we have the basis for growth and self development

name: Kristii Myers
position: Executive Officer, Office Assistant Commissioner, Regulatory Operations, QBCC
text: I am forever humbled by the wonderful kindness I see in the people and place I work in amd let me tell you whyâ€¦.  What I was reminded of this week is that our colleagues are also our biggest supporters even when you donâ€™t know it.  I hosted a morning tea to raise important funds for National Breast Cancer Foundation and can I tell you how full my heart felt? I can never describe how much the human compassion in my colleagues makes me feel.  We have a few ladies who have had the awful diagnosis of breast cancer but none was more heart breaking for me than than one that I work closely with.  The combined efforts from everyone across the organisation resulted in more than $1400 being raised for the NBCFâ€” absolutely smashing our $500 goal and highlighting the generosity of our people. These funds will go directly toward life-saving breast cancer research, helping to make a tangible difference in the lives of many.  A huge thank you to everyone who participated and donated, showing that weâ€™re not just making a difference in our workplace culture but also contributing to the fight against breast cancer. You can still make a donation.  I will forever advocate for workplace health and wellbeing and am forever grateful for working in an organisation that recognises and supports this .

name: Smiti Iyer
position: Student at Symbiosis School of International Studies, Pune | Research | Foreign Policy | Cultural Diplomacy | Climate Diplomacy | Korean Studies
text: As we come to the end of this month, I would like to express my gratitude to The International Academic Forum (IAFOR) for providing me the opportunity to give my presentation at The Korean Conference on Arts amd Humanities (KCAH2024), virtually. My presentation 'Korea's Market Growth of KPOP's Merchandise Trade: Significance of the Research and Development Sector', has highlighted how increase in export of KPOP merchandise has enhanced Korea's Market overall. This rapid increase in the country's market growth strictly requires the establishment of the Research and Development Sector, in order to ensure transparency through reporting and to determine any restrictions imposed on these products domestically and internationally.  I would also like to extend my heartfelt gratitude to the director, deputy director, all the faculties and the administration of the, Pune for their constant support and guidance throughout for my participation in this conference.

text: Powerchip Pivots to 3D AI Foundry, Targets Explosive Growth by 2026  Powerchip is transitioning its Tongluo facility to concentrate on 3D AI contract manufacturing, incorporating interposer and 3D wafer stacking technologies to cater to major clients. Despite market competition from increased wafer foundry capacities, Powerchip has secured customer certification and initiated shipments of high-value interposer products. The company is also collaborating with leading logic foundries, such as AMD, to develop WoW modules for four-layer DRAM wafers, aligning with downstream customers' new product schedules.  Emphasizing the integration of mature process technologies for logic and memory, Powerchip is establishing a cost-efficient 3D AI foundry platformã€‚ With the high added value of interposer and wafer stacking products and lower production equipment investment, Powerchip has deployed an initial capacity of several thousand units and is capable of rapidly expanding production lines to meet customer demands. text: Seek and Destroy Profile Thursday ( Before NFP Friday)  Today we Experienced the Typical Seek and Destroy profile with High Resistance market Opining.  Price took Highs and then Took Lows and then Accumulated Going In PM session we Had Manipulation after Sweeping the External High (ATH) and Internal High and creating High of the Day, Distribution lower to Sweep the AM low and London Lows. Then slowly dropped to Previous Day PM Lows, Completion the Distribution Phase and MMSM.  A+ trade setup today we had 1 A+ setup today at 12:50 Macro. Entry at 1:09, after External and internal Lq sweep, LQ raid, MSS, CISD, SD FIB align with SSL, Pullback to Discounted FVG,Breaker, IFVG and OB ( all entry conditions met ) Instant drop to sell side liquidity. 5R trade with 13 pts SL, 65pts Target.  Besides that we had minor setups But all of them were In High resistance and low Probability Setups.  We had multiple Models Today - MMSM - AMD MODEL - Seek and Destroy profile  NFP week Thu, Most of the time we will See S&D high resistance so keep that in mind these conditions are not easy to trade and can cause you great loses if you are a beginner trader.  Keep in mind these days provide best learning Opportunities for Tape reading, Familiarizing yourself with so called Choppy conditions, Risk OFF mode and Practicing Discipline.  I will Post Analysis and My Recaps Everyday. Stay Tuned and Keep Improving...  See you Tomorrow  Peace

name: Andy Cheng
position: Operations Project Manager @ Lam Research | Ex-Foxconn | PMP
text: 2024 CEO Lisa Su: and The Semiconductor Queen Transforming AMD and Tech Innovation  In the dynamic world of technology, few leaders have made as profound an impact as Dr. Lisa Su, the CEO of AMD, who was recently named TIME Magazine's 2024 CEO of the Year. Her extraordinary journey from a young immigrant to a transformative tech leader is a testament to innovation, strategic vision, and relentless determination.  A Trailblazing Career Born in Taiwan and immigrating to the United States at just three years old, Su's path to success was shaped by her early passion for STEM. With a doctorate in electrical engineering from MIT, she began her career at industry giants like Texas Instruments and IBM, where she was already recognized as a standout innovator under 35.  In 2012, Su joined AMD as a senior executive, and by 2014, she had become CEO. At the time, AMD was struggling, with its stock price hovering around $3 and market share nearly negligible. Fast forward to today, and now trading at about US$140 per share. The transformation is nothing short of remarkable.  Remarkable Achievements Under Su's leadership, AMD has achieved unprecedented success:  - The company's stock has surged nearly 50-fold since her appointment - AMD's market value has overtaken long-time rival Intel - The company has become a key player in the AI revolution  Su's strategic approach goes beyond traditional business management. She is hands-on, often visiting labs to review prototype chips and providing direct feedback to her executive team. Her leadership style is characterized by setting ambitious goals and inspiring her team to achieve them.  Global Recognition and Impact Her achievements have not gone unnoticed. Su has been consistently featured in prestigious lists such as:  - Forbes' "100 Most Influential Women in the World" - Fortune's "Most Powerful Women" - TIME's "100 Most Influential People in AI"  Beyond personal accolades, Su has positioned AMD as a critical player in global technology infrastructure. AMD's chips power everything from personal computers and data centers to the world's most powerful supercomputers and AI applications.  Leadership Philosophy "I don't believe leaders are born; they are trained," Su often says. Her leadership style is characterized by high expectations, continuous learning, and a commitment to developing talent. Her long-term vision includes projecting the specialized AI chip market to reach $500 billion by 2028 â€“ a market larger than the entire semiconductor industry a decade ago.  Dr. Lisa Su represents more than just a successful CEO. She embodies the potential of immigrant success, technological innovation, and strategic leadership. Her journey from a young immigrant to the semiconductor industry's most influential leader is an inspiring narrative of perseverance, vision, and transformative leadership.

name: Francis Benistant
position: Executive Director at Technology Modeling Automation
text: hashtag #semiconductor  hashtag #IDM  hashtag #Foundry  hashtag #intelcorporation  hashtag #boardofdirectors  hashtag #corporategovernance  hashtag #processingtechnology  hashtag #armprocessors  hashtag #x86architecture   The author gives an extensive analysis of Intel's decline which is accurate - except for the Foundry business. The author thinks that Intel shoudl focus on IFS and not on X86 architecture. While only China could build up a Foundry competing with TSMC, the time has passed for the US and UE.  Intel's Board of Directors: A Catalyst for Decline  This paper provides a comprehensive examination of Intel's leadership issues, strategic missteps, and eroding market position.  â€¢ Board incompetence: 7 of 11 members lack relevant semiconductor experience â€¢ Cultural shift: From engineering focus to business-oriented management â€¢ Process technology failures: 10nm node debacle allowed competitors to gain market share â€¢ Erosion of x86 dominance: Rise of Arm-based processors in client and server markets  The authors trace Intel's problems to the appointment of Paul Otellini as CEO, marking a shift from technical leadership to business-oriented management. This change led to a cultural transformation that prioritized political power over technical excellence.  Intel's failure in developing its 10nm process node is identified as a critical turning point, enabling competitors like TSMC and AMD to gain significant market share. The paper also discusses the erosion of Intel's x86 moat in both client and server markets, with Arm-based processors and accelerated computing solutions posing significant threats.  The analysis extends to Intel's financial decisions, criticizing the focus on stock buybacks over capital expenditures during Bob Swan's tenure as CEO. This approach is described as malpractice in a capital-intensive industry when the company was losing market share and lagging in process technology.  The paper argues that Intel's board has made a series of poor decisions, culminating in the dismissal of Pat Gelsinger and a renewed focus on x86 products. The authors contend that this strategy is misguided and unlikely to address Intel's fundamental challenges.  Limitations of the study include potential bias in assessing board decisions and a focus on internal factors without fully exploring external market dynamics. The analysis may also underestimate the challenges faced by Arm-based processors in fully displacing x86 in certain markets.  This comprehensive analysis provides valuable insights into the challenges faced by established technology companies in maintaining market leadership and the critical role of board decisions in shaping a company's trajectory.

name: Deepak gupta
text: MachineGames has already released the first patch for Indiana Jones and the Great Circle (you can see our analysis here), and since the game has been made available to users starting today we can say that it is the typical â€œday one patch.â€ However, it has already become controversial due to the fact that it enables Path Tracing for users who have a graph of NVIDIAbut it leaves the holders of a graph of amd. Letâ€™s explain it.   In fact, although we have already analyzed the new Indiana Jones and the Great Circle, it was because they gave us access to the game beforehand and that means that, what we were able to test it, we were not able to see such outstanding features as Path Tracing, which we Itâ€™s available right now. Well, thatâ€™s if we used an NVIDIA graphics card, of courseâ€¦ Indiana Jones leaves AMD users without FSR As the developer explains in the patch notesâ€œAdded full ray tracing (Path Tracing) functionality for supported NVIDIA graphics cards. To use this function, a graphics card with a minimum of 12 GB of VRAM is required. â€œWe are also working to add support for AMD FSR in a future update.â€ Future update, you know, so for now nothing at all. As you can see in the video embedded above, the visual difference when using Path Tracing is quite interesting, especially in a game like this that supports ray tracing in shadows, reflections and even indirect lighting, settings that can be modified at will in the graphical options within the game. Of course, as you will surely realize if you watch this video, an RTX 4080 suffers quite a bit with all these settings activated, and the FPS drops to practically half.  This is one of the reasons why AMD users will be eagerly waiting for FSR technology to be implemented in Indiana Jones and the Great Circle, since it is a way that, as we have seen on many other occasions, you can play with a high level of frames per second without giving up graphic quality, something that significantly improves the gaming experienceâ€¦ and the truth is, having a fairly top graphics and then having to play at just over 30 FPS is quite unfortunate. This day 1 patch also fixes a good handful of issues and bugs from the preview version, which is the one we played, but it also adds some pretty interesting additional options, such as the â€œreset valuesâ€ option in the Options menu. In any case, practically everything in this patch is to solve problems detected in the initial version, which is why it is more than recommended that, whether you have an NVIDIA or AMD graphics card, you install it. And if your graphics card is AMD, then you will have to wait a little longer (probably a matter of one or two weeks) to be able to enjoy it properly.

name: Joanne Woo
position: Global VP, Division Head of Marketing & Communications at ABB | Curator, TEDxMelbourne
text: Lisa Su, CEO of AMD, has been named TIME's 2024 CEO of the Year, and itâ€™s a well-earned recognition. Her story really resonates with me, and I wanted to share why I find her so inspiring.  Breaking barriers Born in Taiwan and raised in New York City, Lisa discovered her love for STEM early on, even building a hurricane simulator for a school project. She went on to earn a Ph.D. in electrical engineering at MIT, working her way through a male-dominated field to lead one of the most important companies in the world. Today, AMD is at the heart of the technology we use every day, from AI to supercomputing.  Turning AMD around When Lisa became CEO in 2014, AMD was struggling. Its stock was at $3, and people thought the company wouldnâ€™t survive much longer. Under her leadership, AMD has not only survived but thrived, with its stock rising nearly 50-fold. She focused on rebuilding the companyâ€™s products, repairing customer relationships, and simplifying the business. Itâ€™s an incredible turnaround story.  Here's what I've learnt from reading about Lisa's leadership philosophy:  â€¢ Set big goals: She inspired her team by aiming high, like designing a CPU chip that was 40% faster than its predecessor.  â€¢ Focus and simplification matter: She rejected short-term distractions to double down on AMD's strengths, creating clarity and alignment across the organization.  â€¢ Be resilient: She balanced long-term goals with short-term wins to keep the company afloat while giving her team time to innovate.  â€¢ Invest in people: Sheâ€™s known for building strong teams and holding everyone accountable, including herself.  Also, isn't it great to see an Asian American be recognized as CEO of the year? We need to see more diversity in leadership reporting, like this. As my Gen Alpha daughter would say: "she slays!".  Iâ€™m inspired by Lisaâ€™s story of overcoming challenges to lead on a global stage. Sheâ€™s shown that great leadership is about resilience, focus, and empowering others to do their best work.  Lisaâ€™s story reminds me that leadership isnâ€™t about being perfect - itâ€™s about staying the course, making tough decisions, and inspiring people along the way. Congratulations to Lisa on this well-deserved honor.  What do you find most inspiring about Lisaâ€™s story? Iâ€™d love to hear your thoughts.  Read the article here:

name: The Executive Perspective
text: Meet Lisa Su, the CEO of AMD.  Over the past decade, she played a pivotal role in steering   the company through challenging times and driving its remarkable turnaround.  Building on her insights:  At its heart, education is about solving problems,  A timeless purpose that remains unchanged, even as technology continues to advance.  From an early age, learning is centered on identifying challenges and discovering ways to overcome them, whether itâ€™s mastering basic skills like counting, reading, or forming social connections.  As individuals grow, they confront more advanced challenges, from scientific research and mathematical concepts to addressing broader societal issues.  While technology reshapes the tools and methods we use in education, the core objective of nurturing critical thinking, analytical skills, and the ability to devise solutions remains constant.  ğŸ”” Followfor more videos like this.

name: Danielle Z
position: AI Computer Data Analysis Innovation Driver|Technology Leader|AI Solutions Director
text: Liquid AI just raised $250M to develop a more efficient type of AI model Liquid AI, an AI startup co-founded by robotics luminary Daniela Rus, has raised $250 million in a Series A led by AMD. Per Bloomberg, the round values Liquid AI at over $2 billion. Liquid AI aims to build general-purpose AI systems powered by a relatively new type of AI model called a liquid neural network. Liquid neural networks consist of â€œneuronsâ€ governed by equations that predict each individual neuronâ€™s behavior over time. The â€œliquidâ€ bit in the term â€œliquid neural networksâ€ refers to the architectureâ€™s flexibility; inspired by the â€œbrainsâ€ of roundworms, not only are liquid neural networks much smaller than traditional AI models, but they require far less computing power to run.  Liquid AI aims to develop tailored liquid neural networks for applications like e-commerce, consumer electronics, and biotech. As part of AMDâ€™s investment, Liquid AI says itâ€™ll work with the chipmaker to optimize its models for AMDâ€™s GPUs, CPUs, and AI accelerators.
